descripGrp.descrip: To terminate a session with a computer accessed through a communications line usually a computer that is both distant and open to many users.
An interface that is used to navigate the menus of a Unified Messaging (UM) system using DTMF or touchtone inputs.
An interface that is used to navigate the menus of a Unified Messaging (UM) system using DTMF or touchtone inputs.
An interface that is used to navigate the menus of a Unified Messaging (UM) system using DTMF or touchtone inputs.
The part of a service order that specifies detailed information about the requested service.

A logical grouping of managed folders. When a managed folder mailbox policy is applied to a user’s mailbox, all the managed folders that are linked to the policy are deployed in a single operation, thereby making the deployment of messaging records management (MRM) easier.
In communications, the portion of a Data Terminal Equipment (DTE) device that sends data.
A transmission medium designed for high-speed data transfers over long distances. Cable modem services and Digital Subscriber Line (DSL) are examples of broadband networks.
A transmission medium designed for high-speed data transfers over long distances. Cable modem services and Digital Subscriber Line (DSL) are examples of broadband networks.

A piece of the user interface (UI) in Outlook Web Access that can be hosted in iframes as part of other Web applications such as SharePoint Portal Server portals. Outlook Web Access exposes a set of Outlook Web Access Web Part URLs that allow other applications to request certain portions of the Outlook Web Access UI. For example, another application can load the Outlook Web Access Web Part URL for the Inbox, Calendar, or Contact folder into an iframe hosted in that application.
A mark placed over, under, or through a character, usually to indicate a change in phonetic value from the unmarked state.
A mark placed over, under, or through a character, usually to indicate a change in phonetic value from the unmarked state.
A feature that allows you to open any XAML file on your hard disk (or a hyperlink on a web page) and run it within a browser without compilation.
A menu that drops from the menu bar when requested and remains open without further action until the user closes it or chooses a menu item.
A person or company who has the authority to purchase goods and services using a payment card.

The movement of information from one location to another, either within a computer (as from a disk drive to memory), between a computer and an external device (as between a file server and a computer on a network), or between separate computers.

The movement of information from one location to another, either within a computer (as from a disk drive to memory), between a computer and an external device (as between a file server and a computer on a network), or between separate computers.

A server located on a network between client software, such as a Web browser, and another server. It intercepts all requests to the server to determine whether it can fulfill them itself. If not, it forwards the request to another server.

A type of note that helps users apply the techniques and procedures described in the text to their specific needs. A tip suggests alternative methods that may not be obvious and helps users understand the benefits and capabilities of the product. A tip is not essential to the basic understanding of the text.
A method of protecting the rights of an originator of a creative work, such as a text, a piece of music, a painting, or a computer program, through law.

A document that serves as a starting point in a hypertext system. On the World Wide Web, an entry page for a set of Web pages and other files in a Web site. The home page is displayed by default when a visitor navigates to the site using a Web browser.
Any address type that the MS Mail postoffice does not have a gateway or access component installed for routing.

A mail-enabled Active Directory user that represents a user outside the Exchange organization. Each mail user has an external e-mail address. A mail user is similar to a mail contact, except that a mail user has Active Directory logon credentials and can access resources.
The factor used to convert from one unit of measure to another unit of measure, such as from centimeters to meters.

A system of depreciation that assigns depreciation methods to different classes of assets. Created by the Economic Recovery Tax Act of 1981 for U.S. tax purposes and modified by the Tax Reform Act of 1986.

A system of depreciation that assigns depreciation methods to different classes of assets. Created by the Economic Recovery Tax Act of 1981 for U.S. tax purposes and modified by the Tax Reform Act of 1986.

An organizational feature of Windows that displays a panel on the side of the desktop with shortcuts to mini-applications, also known as gadgets. The examples of such gadgets are local weather, a photo slideshow, a dictionary, news headlines, and a Windows Media Player control.
A chronological list of transactions, in the form of debits and credits, for a particular account or group of accounts, such as sales or cash disbursements.

A service or feature of Windows that enables licensing at the feature level; thereby broadening the distribution and licensing options for retailers, ISVs, and OEMs. New business models may include: trials, subscriptions, gifting, transfers, or pay-for-use.

A service or feature of Windows that enables licensing at the feature level; thereby broadening the distribution and licensing options for retailers, ISVs, and OEMs. New business models may include: trials, subscriptions, gifting, transfers, or pay-for-use.

The logon name (and therefore the email address) of an account that is responsible for maintaining email services on a mail server. When an account holder is having trouble with email, a message to postmaster or "postmaster@machine.org.domain.name" will usually reach a human who can solve the problem.

A protocol that provides communications privacy and security between two applications communicating over a network. TLS encrypts communications and enables clients to authenticate servers and, optionally, servers to authenticate clients. TLS is a more secure version of the Secure Sockets Layer (SSL) protocol.

A protocol that provides communications privacy and security between two applications communicating over a network. TLS encrypts communications and enables clients to authenticate servers and, optionally, servers to authenticate clients. TLS is a more secure version of the Secure Sockets Layer (SSL) protocol.
An association established between common fields (columns) in two tables. A relationship can be one-to-one, many-to-many, or one-to-many.
The inability of a computer system or related device to operate reliably or to operate at all.
A business document issued by a carrier to a shipper that serves as the document of title.
A keyboard key (often labeled "PgDn") that is often used to move the cursor down to the top of the next page or a specific number of lines. Its function may vary in different programs.
A filter that helps to identify fraudulent Web sites and protect against personal data theft.
A string substitution performed on XML elements as a document passes through the pipeline.
A member of the Administrators group on the local server computer.

An on-screen element whose location changes as the user moves the mouse. Depending on the location of the mouse pointer and the operation of the program with which it is working, the area of the screen where the mouse pointer appears serves as the target for an action when the user presses one of the mouse buttons.

An on-screen element whose location changes as the user moves the mouse. Depending on the location of the mouse pointer and the operation of the program with which it is working, the area of the screen where the mouse pointer appears serves as the target for an action when the user presses one of the mouse buttons.
A graph that uses vertical bars to show data changes over a period of time or illustrate comparisons among items.
A graph that uses vertical bars to show data changes over a period of time or illustrate comparisons among items.
The user preferences for the formatting of dates, currencies, numbers, and so on. The user locale is a per-user setting, and does not require the user to restart or to log on or log off the computer.
A part of the user interface dedicated to a particular purpose, such as "instant message area."
A data access interface that communicates with OLE DB-compliant data sources to connect to, retrieve, manipulate, and update data.
A data access interface that communicates with OLE DB-compliant data sources to connect to, retrieve, manipulate, and update data.
A keyboard key that alternates between turning a particular operation, function, or mode on or off.
An orientation where the long dimension of a rectangular area (for example, screen or paper) is vertical.
An orientation where the long dimension of a rectangular area (for example, screen or paper) is vertical.
Any combination of keys that must be pressed simultaneously.
Any combination of keys that must be pressed simultaneously.

A digital document that is commonly used for authentication and to help secure information on a network. A certificate binds a public key to an entity that holds the corresponding private key. Certificates are digitally signed by the certification authority that issues them, and they can be issued for a user, a computer, or a service.

A digital document that is commonly used for authentication and to help secure information on a network. A certificate binds a public key to an entity that holds the corresponding private key. Certificates are digitally signed by the certification authority that issues them, and they can be issued for a user, a computer, or a service.
A graphical bar (think bar charts) displayed in each cell. The length of the bar is related to the cell’s value.
To gain entry to memory in order to read or write data.
A module that can contain the definition for a new object. Each instance of a class creates a new object. Procedures defined in the module become properties and methods of the object.
A signal sent by a device to get the attention of the processor when the device is ready to accept or send information.
A signal sent by a device to get the attention of the processor when the device is ready to accept or send information.
A signal sent by a device to get the attention of the processor when the device is ready to accept or send information.
When referring to taxation, funds deducted from salary or other income to cover tax liability.
An object created using drawing tools or commands.

In Exchange 5.5 and earlier, a custom recipient is a user who is not hosted by Exchange. In Exchange 2003, such users can be added to Active Directory as contacts, Windows users, or users whose Windows accounts are disabled. In any case, they are mail-enabled, but not mailbox-enabled, because their mailboxes are hosted on another messaging system.
A combination of list formatting options identified by a style name.
Any temporary storage space used within or in conjunction with a computer, such as RAM or a USB flash drive.
A unit of computer or device memory equal to 1,024 megabytes (1,024 1,048,576, [230] bytes).
A unit of computer or device memory equal to 1,024 megabytes (1,024 1,048,576, [230] bytes).
The date a transaction physically occurred, such as the date that an item was received.

A list of names and e-mail addresses that are grouped under a single name. When a user places the name of the mailing list in a mail client's To: field, the client sends the message to the machine where the mailing list resides, and that machine automatically sends the message to all the addresses on the list (possibly allowing a moderator to edit it first).

The process of granting a person, computer process, or device access to certain information, services or functionality. Authorization is derived from the identity of the person, computer process, or device requesting access, which is verified through authentication.
A standard Windows control that supports scrolling.
To organize information, such as a list of files, in a particular order. For example, a list of files can be sorted alphabetically by name in ascending or descending order.
A data file consisting of fields and records, stored as text, in which the fields are separated from each other by commas.
A data file consisting of fields and records, stored as text, in which the fields are separated from each other by commas.
A data file consisting of fields and records, stored as text, in which the fields are separated from each other by commas.
A reference to data stored in a document from another program.

A defined interval of time in which users can post inventory transactions. An inventory period can be closed to prevent any value changes to inventory (expected or invoiced) from being posted with a posting date in the closed period. It is, however, possible to apply an item quantity to an open item ledger entry in a closed period.
The worksheet area into which you drag PivotTable or PivotChart fields to change the layout of the report. On a new report, dashed blue outlines indicate the pivot area on the worksheet.
An XML vocabulary that is used to transform XML data to another form, such as HTML, by means of a style sheet that defines presentation rules.
An XML vocabulary that is used to transform XML data to another form, such as HTML, by means of a style sheet that defines presentation rules.
To press and release a mouse button twice in rapid succession without moving the mouse. Double-clicking is a means of rapidly selecting and activating a program or program feature.
The operational state of a computer or a program. For example, edit mode is the state in which a program accepts changes to a file.
Any disk drive, folder, or other place in which you can store files and folders. Programs will commonly ask you to choose a location to save a file.
Any disk drive, folder, or other place in which you can store files and folders. Programs will commonly ask you to choose a location to save a file.
The prepayment amount that has been deducted from ordinary invoices (that is, not prepayment invoices) for a sales or purchase line.

A comment created by using a stylus. Microsoft Office Word treats a pen comment like any other drawing object. Pen comments don't appear in the Reviewing Pane, and Word doesn't insert comment marks in the document window.
Software that enables hardware or peripherals (such as a printer, mouse, or keyboard) to work with your computer or mobile device.
Software that enables hardware or peripherals (such as a printer, mouse, or keyboard) to work with your computer or mobile device.
An object-oriented programming language, developed by Sun Microsystems, Inc.
A set of technologies that allows software components to interact with one another in a networked environment, regardless of the language in which the components were created.
The translation of field data values based on business rules.
The + character, used to indicate addition or a positive number.
A connection between an OLE object and its OLE server, or between a dynamic data exchange (DDE) source document and a destination document.
A connection between an OLE object and its OLE server, or between a dynamic data exchange (DDE) source document and a destination document.
To set up hardware and software.
A location on a SharePoint site where a collection of files and their associated metadata are stored.
A location on a SharePoint site where a collection of files and their associated metadata are stored.
Not in the immediate vicinity, as a computer or other device located in another place (room, building, or city) and accessible through some type of cable or communications link.

A hardware- or software-based interface used to transfer information between a computer and other devices. Hardware ports are physical connections that are visible on the outside of the computer. Software ports are the numbered gateways in programs that software programs use to exchange information.
Referring to anything that is ready for immediate use by a user or application.
A payment policy that requires payment in full for product upon delivery.
A payment policy that requires payment in full for product upon delivery.

A feature of Windows Vista that gives the user quick access to useful information on their computer, such as calendar appointments and the latest e-mail message even when the computer is in standby mode or hibernating, media playback control when the computer is off, and other application notifications.
In e-mail and Internet newsgroups, the content of a message. The body of a message follows the header, which contains information about the sender, origin, and destination of the message.
A server that makes data available for replication to other servers. A Publisher also detects changed data and maintains information about all publications at the site.
A cryptographic algorithm specified by the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) to protect sensitive information.
A cryptographic algorithm specified by the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) to protect sensitive information.
A fee that is attached to a collection letter and charged to the delinquent debtor.
Software for capturing, editing, and arranging audio and video source material to create movies.
Software for capturing, editing, and arranging audio and video source material to create movies.

Microsoft Web server software, utilizing the Hypertext Transfer Protocol (HTTP) to deliver World Wide Web documents. Supports the Common Gateway Interface (CGI), the File Transfer Protocol (FTP), and Gopher.

Microsoft Web server software, utilizing the Hypertext Transfer Protocol (HTTP) to deliver World Wide Web documents. Supports the Common Gateway Interface (CGI), the File Transfer Protocol (FTP), and Gopher.
Each of a set of references that together describe the exact position of something with respect to a set of axes (or a row and column).
A sales invoice that is created from an original sales order.
The percentage of the sales invoice amount that a customer has to prepay.
The timing and sequence of tasks within a project.
A file that lists errors that were encountered during an operation.

An input device used to control an on-screen cursor for such actions as "pressing" on-screen buttons in dialog boxes, choosing menu items, and selecting ranges of cells in spreadsheets or groups of words in a document.
The ÷ character.
A character or symbol that indicates a relationship between two or more values or expressions — for example, < (less than), > (greater than), and = (equal to).
Without difficulty.

An object that is inserted into a document but still exists in the source file. When information is linked, the new document is updated automatically if the information in the original document changes.
An application that usually includes an address book and organizes unrelated information, such as notes, appointments, and names, in a useful way.

A tested, cumulative set of all hotfixes, security updates, critical updates and updates, as well as additional fixes for problems found internally since the release of the product. Service packs may also contain a limited number of customer requested design changes or features, and contain all fixes since the previous service pack or RTM.

A tested, cumulative set of all hotfixes, security updates, critical updates and updates, as well as additional fixes for problems found internally since the release of the product. Service packs may also contain a limited number of customer requested design changes or features, and contain all fixes since the previous service pack or RTM.
A diagram that is used to show a process that has a continuous cycle.
A collection of users that have been assigned identical access permissions.
The "one" side of two related tables in a one-to-many relationship. A primary table should have a primary key and each record should be unique.
The ´ character.

In reference to a single microcomputer, the sum of a system's internal and external components, including memory, disk drives, keyboard, video, and generally less critical add-on hardware, such as a mouse, modem, or printer. Software (the operating system and various device drivers), the user's choices established through configuration files such as the AUTOEXEC.BAT and CONFIG.SYS files on IBM PCs and compatibles, and sometimes hardware (switches and jumpers) are needed to "configure the configuration" to work correctly. Although system configuration can be changed, as by adding more memory or disk capacity, the basic structure of the system--its architecture--remains the same.

The range of cells that you select to hold the summarized data in a consolidation. The destination area can be on the same worksheet as the source data or on a different worksheet. A worksheet can contain only one consolidation.
A source document that documents an agreement between two parties based on an understanding that one party will commit to paying the other party at a specified time or on demand.
A type of chart that displays the trend of values over time or categories. By displaying the sum of the plotted values, an area chart also shows the relationship of parts to a whole.

A physical or logical division within a warehouse, defined for efficient resource utilization. A zone might be identified by type of materials stored, by type of equipment used, or by assigned picker.

To reconcile the differences between files, e-mail, appointments, and other items stored on one computer, device or in the cloud with versions of the same files on another computer, device or in the cloud. Once the differences are determined, both sets of items are updated.

To reconcile the differences between files, e-mail, appointments, and other items stored on one computer, device or in the cloud with versions of the same files on another computer, device or in the cloud. Once the differences are determined, both sets of items are updated.
A type of calculation that combines source data in a PivotTable report or a consolidation table, or when you are inserting automatic subtotals in a list or database.
The area along the edges of a page that cannot be printed on. Different printers have different nonprinting regions.
A list of the references in a legal document, such as references to cases, statutes, and rules, along with the numbers of the pages the references appear on.
A list of the references in a legal document, such as references to cases, statutes, and rules, along with the numbers of the pages the references appear on.
The location where the user is currently directing input.
A style of processing where an application requests that an event occurs and waits for the event to complete, so that the application is certain of the result of its request before it proceeds.
A field that must contain a value if a record is updated or inserted into the database.
A challenge meant to be easily solved by humans, while remaining too hard to be economically solved by computers.

A folder that provides you with a convenient place to store documents, graphics, or other files you want to access quickly. When you save a file in a program such as WordPad or Paint, the file is automatically saved in My Documents, unless you choose a different folder.

A page of information about the broadcast that is displayed in the viewer's browser before the broadcast begins. It can contain a title, subject, host's name, information about the broadcast, and a countdown to the time of the broadcast.
A program designed to amuse or scare a user, for example by imitating the actions of a virus, without actually harming the computer.
The set of coordinates that a cell occupies on a worksheet. For example, the reference of the cell that appears at the intersection of column B and row 3 is B3.
A tutorial outlining basic Windows features, workflow and information.
One of the colors defined in a set of chosen colors. If you fill an object with a scheme color, the object's color changes whenever you choose another color scheme for that publication.
A fraction that is written on a single line: the numerator is placed on the left, followed by the fraction bar, and the denominator on the right. Example: 3/4

A hyphen that is used to control where a word or phrase breaks if it falls at the end of a line. For example, you can specify that the word "nonprinting" breaks as "non-printing" rather than "nonprint-ing."

A hyphen that is used to control where a word or phrase breaks if it falls at the end of a line. For example, you can specify that the word "nonprinting" breaks as "non-printing" rather than "nonprint-ing."

A hyphen that is used to control where a word or phrase breaks if it falls at the end of a line. For example, you can specify that the word "nonprinting" breaks as "non-printing" rather than "nonprint-ing."

To transfer information either to a storage device, such as a disk, or to an output device, such as the monitor or a printer. Writing is the means by which a computer provides the results of processing. A computer can also be said to write to the screen when it displays information on the monitor.

A computer program designed to detect and respond to malicious software, such as viruses and worms. Responses may include blocking user access to infected files, cleaning infected files or systems, or informing the user that an infected program was detected.

A computer program designed to detect and respond to malicious software, such as viruses and worms. Responses may include blocking user access to infected files, cleaning infected files or systems, or informing the user that an infected program was detected.

A computer program designed to detect and respond to malicious software, such as viruses and worms. Responses may include blocking user access to infected files, cleaning infected files or systems, or informing the user that an infected program was detected.
Any self-contained piece of work created with an application program and, if saved on disk, given a unique filename by which it can be retrieved.
Any self-contained piece of work created with an application program and, if saved on disk, given a unique filename by which it can be retrieved.

A type of object within a process that runs program instructions. Using multiple threads allows concurrent operations within a process and enables one process to run different parts of its program on different processors simultaneously. A thread has its own set of registers, its own kernel stack, a thread environment block, and a user stack in the address space of its process.
Not visible to the user.
A credit animation in Windows Movie Maker.
To gradually write off the regular portion of the cost of an asset over the projected life of the asset.
A method of depreciation that calculates the depreciation of a fixed asset as a fixed amount in each depreciation period.
To transfer digital data in a continuous flow across a network.
Hardware that transfers audio and video from an external source, such as a VCR or camcorder, to a computer.
A number that gives a general indication of the performance capability of your computer's hardware.
A workflow instance that is generated by a parent workflow instance.

On the IBM PC/XT and AT and compatible keyboards, a key on the top row of the numeric keypad that controls the effect of the cursor control keys and sometimes prevents the screen from scrolling. On the enhanced and Macintosh keyboards, this key is to the right of the function keys on the top row. Many modern applications ignore the Scroll Lock setting.
A part of an IrDA infrared communication protocol used so that devices can learn about the services offered by another device.
A part of an IrDA infrared communication protocol used so that devices can learn about the services offered by another device.

In object-oriented programming, a language that lets a program or object written in one language communicate with another program written in an unknown language. An IDL is used to define interfaces between client and server programs. For example, an IDL can provide interfaces to remote CORBA objects.
A graphic design applied to a collection of numbers, symbols, and characters. A font describes a certain typeface, along with other qualities such as size, spacing, and pitch.
In the United States, the postal code assigned to all addresses.

An operating system feature that allows executable routines (generally serving a specific function or set of functions) to be stored separately as files with .dll extensions. These routines are loaded only when needed by the program that calls them.

An operating system feature that allows executable routines (generally serving a specific function or set of functions) to be stored separately as files with .dll extensions. These routines are loaded only when needed by the program that calls them.
The block of filled-in cells that includes the currently selected cell or cells. The region extends in all directions to the first empty row or column.
A circular or pamphlet for distribution, normally used for advertisements.
In a formula, the exact address of a cell, regardless of the position of the cell that contains the formula.
Digital media that is delivered in a continuous flow across a network.
A computer, device or program that connects to or requests the services of another computer, device or program.
A computer, device or program that connects to or requests the services of another computer, device or program.
The branch of accounting concerned with identifying and evaluating the cost of producing a product.
To remove unused space from data tables.
An item on the File menu that writes data (typically a file) to a storage medium.
Text or symbols indicating that a computer program is waiting for input from the user.

An expression that yields a Boolean value (true or false). Such expressions can involve comparisons (testing values for equality or, for non-­Boolean values, the < [less than] or > [greater than] relation) and logical combination (using Boolean operators such as AND, OR, and XOR) of Boolean expressions.

An expression that yields a Boolean value (true or false). Such expressions can involve comparisons (testing values for equality or, for non-­Boolean values, the < [less than] or > [greater than] relation) and logical combination (using Boolean operators such as AND, OR, and XOR) of Boolean expressions.
A font effect in which lowercase text appears as capital letters in a reduced font size.
An on-screen scale marked off in inches or other units of measure and used to show line widths, tab settings, paragraph indents, and so on.
To gain access to a specific computer, program, or network by identifying oneself with a username and a password.

A compliance-focused agent that is configured to journal e-mail messages that are sent or received by departments or individuals in an Exchange Server 2007 organization, to and from recipients outside the organization, or both for use in the organization's e-mail retention or archival strategy.
Comments that users attach to Web pages and documents.

An international messaging standard that can be used by a variety of messaging systems. X.400 uses a strict addressing method that reflects a hierarchical environment. The use of X.400 has been largely supplanted by the combination of SMTP and MIME.

The work area on a computer screen that simulates the top of an actual desk. The desktop contains the Recycle Bin and other icons (shortcuts to programs, files, folders, and various types of documents such as letters, reports, or pictures) that you can arrange on the electronic desktop just as you would arrange real objects on top of a desk.

The process of starting or resetting a computer or a device. When first turned on (cold boot) or reset (warm boot), the computer runs the software that loads and starts the computer's operating system, which prepares it for use.

The process of starting or resetting a computer or a device. When first turned on (cold boot) or reset (warm boot), the computer runs the software that loads and starts the computer's operating system, which prepares it for use.
A fraction that is written on a downward angle: the diagonal fraction bar is placed down and to the right of the numerator, and the denominator is slightly down and to the right of the fraction bar.
To remove the digital signature added to the document.

Management of a computer and its processing abilities so as to maintain order as tasks and activities are carried out. Control applies to measures designed to ensure error-free actions carried out at the right time and in the right order relative to other data-handling or hardware-based activities.
A collection of graphic or text buttons representing hyperlinks to pages both within your Web site and to external sites.
Of or pertaining to a device or service that appears to the user as something it actually is not or that does not physically exist.
A Windows CE-based application that enables remote users to connect to a network.
A Windows CE-based application that enables remote users to connect to a network.
To determine the total quantities of components needed for a manufactured item.

Having two components, alternatives, or outcomes. The binary number system has 2 as its base, so values are expressed as combinations of two digits, 0 and 1. These two digits can represent the logical values true and false as well as numerals, and they can be represented in an electronic device by the two states on and off, recognized as two voltage levels. Therefore, the binary number system is at the heart of digital computing.
A variable-length data type that can hold a maximum of 2^30 - 1 (1,073,741,823) characters.
How a program's action is determined if the user does not make a choice or supply a required value.
The bill provided by the seller to the buyer for items or services that have been purchased.
A note or annotation that an author or reviewer adds to a document.

A software program that uses Hypertext Transfer Protocol (HTTP) for its core communication protocol and that delivers Web-based information to the user in the Hypertext Markup Language (HTML) language.

A software program that uses Hypertext Transfer Protocol (HTTP) for its core communication protocol and that delivers Web-based information to the user in the Hypertext Markup Language (HTML) language.

A System Audio Effects (SYSFX) component used to provide a more immersive audio experience in the Windows Media Player and thus an improved listening experience by utilizing the available speakers that a user has attached to his/her PC by sending audio to all of the speakers, regardless of the number of channels the content contains. This will provide a better sounding experience for stereo and quadraphonic content being rendered on multi-channel playback systems.
A transaction for items moving to inventory (receipts) or from inventory (issues).

An optional Microsoft Exchange 2000 Server component that is installed on a designated server in an administrative group. It provides centralized administration and archival of private keys, and maintains every user s private encryption key in an encrypted database. The keys are used for encrypting e-mail messages and signing messages with digital signatures.
The Assistant is the shared Microsoft Office Assistant object. It is a fully programmable object.

A home part that allows the user to view all notes that are addressed to them. We will not be able to implement Notifications as described in the POR for Dynamics NAV 5.0. Therefore we will implement My Notes instead. When the user clicks the note link in their My Notes home part, the task page that contains the note will appear. My Notes is a list-based system where users can view all note that are addressed to them. Users will be able to view the following fields: To, From, Description. On task pages, users can write a note and then select users they want to whom they send the note.
The sum of posted depreciations for all the periods in which a fixed asset has been in service.
A binary number that uniquely identifies a host (computer) connected to the Internet to other Internet hosts, for the purposes of communication through the transfer of packets.
A monetary debt or obligation of future services.

A technology that uses radio frequencies to identify products. An RFID-capable product has an RFID tag that can transmit information, such as serial number, to an RF reader, which converts the information into digital data that can be sent to a computer.

A technology that uses radio frequencies to identify products. An RFID-capable product has an RFID tag that can transmit information, such as serial number, to an RF reader, which converts the information into digital data that can be sent to a computer.
A collection of e-mail addresses that is treated as a single recipient for e-mail distribution purposes, and that is created by and available to an individual Outlook user.
A program that enables users to send and receive business card information digitally. Data storage is shared with Outlook.
An authentication mechanism that is supported by most browsers, including Internet Explorer, and encodes (but does not encrypt) user name and password data before transmitting it over the network.
An authentication mechanism that is supported by most browsers, including Internet Explorer, and encodes (but does not encrypt) user name and password data before transmitting it over the network.
A process for removing redundant data from a digital media file or stream to reduce its size or the bandwidth used.

A Windows Server 2003 technology that supports creation of single point-in-time shadow copies - also known as snapshots - of single or multiple volumes without impacting file server performance. Volume Shadow Copy Service also supports backups of open files.

A Windows Server 2003 technology that supports creation of single point-in-time shadow copies - also known as snapshots - of single or multiple volumes without impacting file server performance. Volume Shadow Copy Service also supports backups of open files.

A private telephone network in an organization. Individual telephone numbers or extension numbers are supported, and calls are automatically routed to them. Users can call each other using extensions. They can also place calls to outside numbers.
Any form of money, including bills and coins, used as a medium of exchange.
A distinctive symbol that identifies you, your business, or your organization. It can combine a name, motto, and graphics.
A classifier that classifies organizations in an industry classification system.
A business location to which resources are assigned. A site is used to ensure that all resources required for a service are in the same physical location.
A bar chart subtype that shows the relationship of individual items to the whole.
A processor, distinct from the main microprocessor, that performs additional functions or assists the main microprocessor.
An agreement between a service provider and a customer that specifies the amount and type of service the provider will deliver.
To translate all the source code of a program from a high-level language into object code prior to execution of the program.
To translate all the source code of a program from a high-level language into object code prior to execution of the program.
An internal project for which only hour transactions are registered.
The first row in a spreadsheet. The header row contains category labels that describe the contents of the columns.
To display the subentries contained within a folder or outline view.

In the United States, a Taxpayer Identification Number assigned to citizens and some noncitizens. The number is required for anyone to obtain work or to receive governmental benefits, such as social security payments after retirement.

In the United States, a Taxpayer Identification Number assigned to citizens and some noncitizens. The number is required for anyone to obtain work or to receive governmental benefits, such as social security payments after retirement.
The collection, storing, and sharing of information in a single system where many users can access it.
A command that will use a print driver installed by OneNote to create an image of a wide variety of filetypes. Files are printed to the print driver and inserted as images into OneNote.
A system of programs and workstations used in designing engineering, architectural, and scientific models ranging from simple tools to buildings, aircraft, integrated circuits, and molecules.

The key arrangement used for a particular keyboard, including such factors as the number of keys (101 is the current standard) and the configuration of the keys (QWERTY is the United States standard). Some proprietary systems use different layouts, and many allow you to map the keys to characters according to your preferences.
In a PC-compatible computer, the disk drive that the BIOS uses to automatically load the operating system when the computer is turned on.
A parent project that is used only for structuring information and against which no transactions are registered.

A specification for connecting users on an Ethernet network to the Internet through a broadband connection, such as a single DSL line, wireless device, or cable modem. Using PPPoE and a broadband modem, LAN users can gain individual authenticated access to high-speed data networks. By combining Ethernet and Point-to-Point Protocol (PPP), PPPoE provides an efficient way to create a separate connection for each user to a remote server.

A specification for connecting users on an Ethernet network to the Internet through a broadband connection, such as a single DSL line, wireless device, or cable modem. Using PPPoE and a broadband modem, LAN users can gain individual authenticated access to high-speed data networks. By combining Ethernet and Point-to-Point Protocol (PPP), PPPoE provides an efficient way to create a separate connection for each user to a remote server.
The individual, or account, to whom an e-mail message is sent.
One of four fields of an SCODE. It is a unique number that is assigned to represent the error or warning.

The software that controls the allocation and usage of hardware resources such as memory, central processing unit (CPU) time, disk space, and peripheral devices. The operating system is the foundation on which programs are built.
To press and release a mouse button once without moving the mouse. Clicking is usually performed to select or deselect an item or to activate a program or program feature.

The degree to which a computer, an attached device, a data file, or a program can work with or understand the same commands, formats, or language as another. True compatibility means that any operational differences are invisible to people and programs alike.

Existing in reference to two measures, such as height and width--for example, a two-dimensional model drawn with reference to an x-axis and a y-axis, or a two-dimensional array of numbers placed in rows and columns.

Existing in reference to two measures, such as height and width--for example, a two-dimensional model drawn with reference to an x-axis and a y-axis, or a two-dimensional array of numbers placed in rows and columns.
Pertaining to something for which an answer is not available or appropriate.
Pertaining to something for which an answer is not available or appropriate.
Pertaining to something for which an answer is not available or appropriate.
A set of requests or transactions that have been grouped together.
A parameter that does not take an argument.
Text displayed by Web browsers during image downloads for users who have graphics turned off, and for users who rely on screen-reading software to convert graphics on the screen to spoken words.
A profit taken on the sold item, taking into consideration changes in the original purchase prices of the goods.
Anything owned or controlled by a business, tangible or intangible, that has monetary value and was acquired at a measurable cost.
A static report that contains data captured at a specific point in time.
A static report that contains data captured at a specific point in time.
A collection of products used for presentation, sales campaigns, or e-business.

A statement issued by an online service that indicates what activities users may or may not engage in while logged into the service. For example, some providers prohibit users from engaging in commercial activity on the network.

A statement issued by an online service that indicates what activities users may or may not engage in while logged into the service. For example, some providers prohibit users from engaging in commercial activity on the network.
A monitor designed to work with a video card or adapter to produce text or graphics images in color.
The point size of a set of characters in a particular typeface.
A menu option that displays the folders available in your mailbox.
The time period used for depreciating business assets.
A toggle key that, when on, shifts the alphabetic characters on the keyboard to uppercase.
A toggle key that, when on, shifts the alphabetic characters on the keyboard to uppercase.
A user’s private information such as temporary files, history, passwords, web form entries, and cookies that captures Internet surfing and other online activities.
A set of strategies for adjusting the recognizer to an individual’s user’s handwriting, e.g. the shapes of their characters or the specific words they use and don’t use.
An official notice of a bank transaction.

A password that cannot be easily guessed or cracked. A strong password is at least eight characters long, does not contain all or part of the user's account name, and contains at least three of the four following categories of characters: uppercase characters, lowercase characters, numbers, and symbols found on the keyboard (such as !, @, #).

A set of routines that an application uses to request and carry out lower-level services performed by a computer's or device's operating system. These routines usually carry out maintenance tasks such as managing files and displaying information.
Address Rewriting agent for messages that enter an Exchange Server 2007 organization.
A data type that holds floating-point number data from -1.79E + 308 through 1.79E + 308. float, double precision, and float(n) are SQL Server float data types.
To reduce the size of a set of data, such as a file or a communications message, so that it can be stored in less space or transmitted with less bandwidth.

A concept that implements a single function point of a transport messaging policy. A transport rule contains conditions as to when to trigger this rule and an ordered set of actions as to what to do if the rule is triggered. Additionally, each transport rule can have exceptions that specify what to exclude from the condition. Exceptions typically identify a subset of criteria identified in the condition.
A phrase that clearly indicates to the customer to begin reading instructions at this point.
An orientation of printed paper where the printed side is away from a surface. For example, paper is face up when it is placed in a copier with the printed side away from the copying surface.

A frame that can contain check boxes, toggle buttons, and option buttons on a form, report, or data access page. You use an option group to present alternatives from which the user can select a single option.

A technical article, written and distributed by Microsoft, that provides additional information about a Microsoft product or a fix for a known issue. May include a disk that contains new software, documentation, or sample files.
To extend over and cover a part of something.
Margins of the left page are a mirror image of those of the right page. That is, the inside margins are the same width, and the outside margins are the same width.
Information that cannot be found or recovered.
An interim method of recording commission until payment for the sale is actually collected and paid to the salesperson.
A field that appears in a form, report, or class and that contains and displays data but is not stored as a record in a table. A display field can be calculated data.
A contract that restricts disclosure of confidential information or proprietary knowledge.
A project that is a component of another project.
To compare and adjust two or more accounts or statements so that the figures agree.
A window that appears when an option is selected. Typically, the window remains visible until the mouse button is released.
The practice of reconciling accounts.

When a hyperlink uses a path based on a relative link, you can move the file that contains the hyperlink and the hyperlink destination without breaking the hyperlink. Move the file that contains the hyperlink and its destination together.
A UI element that enables a user to repeat an image so that it fills the page.
An optical disc format used to store video on standard compact discs developed by China Recording Standards Committee in competition to the DVD format.
An optical disc format used to store video on standard compact discs developed by China Recording Standards Committee in competition to the DVD format.
A file consisting of data in the form of text, numbers, or graphics, as distinct from a program file of commands and instructions.
The indication that the phone is busy.

A calculated value that is used to test data for the presence of errors that can occur when data is transmitted or when it is written to disk. The checksum is calculated for a given chunk of data by sequentially combining all the bytes of data with a series of arithmetic or logical operations. After the data is transmitted or stored, a new checksum is calculated in the same way using the (possibly faulty) transmitted or stored data. If the two checksums do not match, an error has occurred, and the data should be transmitted or stored again. Checksums cannot detect all errors, and they cannot be used to correct erroneous data.
Current good manufacturing practices for the manufacture, packaging, and holding of finished pharmaceuticals and drugs.
Current good manufacturing practices for the manufacture, packaging, and holding of finished pharmaceuticals and drugs.

A common method for transmitting non-text data through Internet e-mail. MIME encodes non-text data as ASCII text and then decodes it back to its original format at the receiving end. A MIME header is added to the file which includes the type of data contained and the encoding method used.

A common method for transmitting non-text data through Internet e-mail. MIME encodes non-text data as ASCII text and then decodes it back to its original format at the receiving end. A MIME header is added to the file which includes the type of data contained and the encoding method used.
A grouping of dimension members or items from a data source that are named and treated as a single unit and can be referenced or reused multiple times.
A grouping of dimension members or items from a data source that are named and treated as a single unit and can be referenced or reused multiple times.
An orientation of printed paper where the printed side is against a surface. For example, paper is face down when it is placed in a copier with the printed side against the copying surface.

A family of Microsoft Web-based team collaboration environments that provide the ability to create and access virtual workspaces for managing documents, discussions, lists, surveys and other important contextual information such as team member status and presence.
A source document that documents an offer to supply a quantity of product for a specified price and by a specified date in response to a request for quotation in a sales process.
Shading made up of regularly spaced, intersecting lines.
Shading made up of regularly spaced, intersecting lines.

The information contained in an e-mail message that is required to send and deliver a message between messaging servers by using SMTP protocol commands. The message envelope contains the sender e-mail address and the recipient e-mail address information. Recipients never see the message envelope, because it is not part of the message content, and it is discarded when the message reaches its destination. The X.400 messaging standard equivalent to the message envelope is called the "P1 header." The message envelope is often referred to as the "P1 header."

The information contained in an e-mail message that is required to send and deliver a message between messaging servers by using SMTP protocol commands. The message envelope contains the sender e-mail address and the recipient e-mail address information. Recipients never see the message envelope, because it is not part of the message content, and it is discarded when the message reaches its destination. The X.400 messaging standard equivalent to the message envelope is called the "P1 header." The message envelope is often referred to as the "P1 header."
The smallest rectangle that can enclose the text in a text frame.
The smallest rectangle that can enclose the text in a text frame.
A graphic map that can document procedures, analyze processes, indicate work or information flow, or track cost and efficiency.
A pictorial graphic such as a digital photograph or illustration.
A pictorial graphic such as a digital photograph or illustration.
A pictorial graphic such as a digital photograph or illustration.

An advanced file system designed for use specifically with the Windows NT operating system. It supports long filenames, full security access control, file system recovery, extremely large storage media, and various features for the Windows NT POSIX subsystem. It also supports object-oriented applications by treating all files as objects with user-defined and system-defined attributes.

An advanced file system designed for use specifically with the Windows NT operating system. It supports long filenames, full security access control, file system recovery, extremely large storage media, and various features for the Windows NT POSIX subsystem. It also supports object-oriented applications by treating all files as objects with user-defined and system-defined attributes.
A fundamental unit of measure in a system of measurement from which other units are derived.
A folder that stores messages that have been created but not yet sent.
Pertaining to text that is aligned along the right margin.
A nonprinting mark you insert to show the end of a section.
The unique, 25-character code on a prepaid card that adds computer use time to your prepaid computer or that pays for your subscription.
A feature of Microsoft SQL Server used to import, export, and transform data from different data sources.
A transaction where items come into inventory.
A transaction where items come into inventory.

The standard used to measure screen and printer resolution, expressed as the number of dots that a device can display or print per linear inch. The greater the number of dots per inch, the better the resolution.

The standard used to measure screen and printer resolution, expressed as the number of dots that a device can display or print per linear inch. The greater the number of dots per inch, the better the resolution.

A form of trojan that causes systems equipped with modems to dial phone numbers without the consent of the user. In most cases, the phone numbers dialed are premium rate numbers which result in unexpected charges on the affected user's phone bill.
A handling unit for storing and transferring items.
A tool used to ensure that a file or directory on a client computer contains the same data as a matching file or directory on a server.
An encoding mechanism that converts binary data into printable ASCII characters so that the data can be included in the message body without violating SMTP conventions.

A view that summarizes and analyzes data in a datasheet or form. You can use different levels of detail or organize data by dragging the fields and items, or by showing and hiding items in the drop-down lists for the fields.
A report contained within another report.

A group of related web pages that is hosted by an HTTP server on the World Wide Web or an intranet. The pages in a website typically cover one or more topics and are interconnected through hyperlinks.

A device that enables the transmission of typed messages over phone lines. These devices typically include keyboards for typing messages to send and display and/or printers to receive messages from one device to another.

A device that enables the transmission of typed messages over phone lines. These devices typically include keyboards for typing messages to send and display and/or printers to receive messages from one device to another.

A device that enables the transmission of typed messages over phone lines. These devices typically include keyboards for typing messages to send and display and/or printers to receive messages from one device to another.

A device that enables the transmission of typed messages over phone lines. These devices typically include keyboards for typing messages to send and display and/or printers to receive messages from one device to another.

A device that enables the transmission of typed messages over phone lines. These devices typically include keyboards for typing messages to send and display and/or printers to receive messages from one device to another.
A unique identifier for a transaction or group of transactions.
Properties, such as title, subject, and author, that are stored with each data access page.
Pertaining to a type of layout consisting of a collection of “Row-Wise Groupings”. A stacked layout most resembles a form with name/value pairs (label, textbox).
The main or default (start-up) screen.
The designation of a quantity of inventory on a purchase order for a specific sales order or production schedule.

A set of networking protocols widely used on the Internet that provides communications across interconnected networks of computers with diverse hardware architectures and various operating systems. TCP/IP includes standards for how computers communicate and conventions for connecting networks and routing traffic.

A set of networking protocols widely used on the Internet that provides communications across interconnected networks of computers with diverse hardware architectures and various operating systems. TCP/IP includes standards for how computers communicate and conventions for connecting networks and routing traffic.

The increase in the value of an asset calculated as the difference in the value of the asset when two economic events occur and when the difference is recognized on the occurrence of the second event as an increase in wealth.

The process of transforming e-mail messages from one format to another for the purpose of mail flow or storage, such as MAPI to MIME, or uuencode to Base64 encoded, or for appropriate rendering that is specific to an e-mail client, such as HTML to RTF to plain text.

An optical input device that uses light-sensing equipment to capture an image on paper or some other object. Captured image data is converted into binary files that can be stored and manipulated by computer programs.

A device that connects networks using different communications protocols so that information can be passed from one to the other. A gateway both transfers information and converts it to a form compatible with the protocols used by the receiving network.
A group of computers that are connected on a network and share resources, such as printers and files.
A group of computers that are connected on a network and share resources, such as printers and files.
The processes involved in the capture, storage, display, and printing of graphical images.
A window that mimics an old MS-DOS display for typing command-line instructions.
To emphasize displayed characters, as by displaying them in reverse video (light on dark rather than dark on light, and vice versa) or against a colored background.
A collection of data formatted/arranged to allow for easy search and retrieval.

An information source that contains data about users, computer files, or other objects. In a file system, a directory stores information about files. In a distributed computing environment (such as a Windows domain), the directory stores information about objects such as printers, fax servers, applications, databases, and users.
A policy that determines which XML elements in a document are valid for a particular action associated with an endpoint.
A policy that determines which XML elements in a document are valid for a particular action associated with an endpoint.
A subdivision of a larger campaign.

A tool which enables users to automatically perform routine tasks on a chosen computer by monitoring whatever criteria the users choose to initiate the tasks (referred to as triggers) and then executing the tasks when the criteria is met.

Guidelines, originally developed for the pharmaceutical industry and used in the healthcare industry, for validating that automated systems meet agreed-upon specifications and comply with regulations.

Guidelines, originally developed for the pharmaceutical industry and used in the healthcare industry, for validating that automated systems meet agreed-upon specifications and comply with regulations.
A feature that allows the user to rescue work if the computer crashes for any reason.
A row in the upper part of the Macro window in which you enter macro names, actions, conditions, and comments associated with a particular macro or macro group.
A set of characteristics that are assigned to a fixed asset. The fixed asset inherits the characteristics (such as type, number sequences, and default value models) from the group.
Pertaining to the device, program, file, record or portion of the screen that is currently operational or subject to command operations.

A value that a function or a method uses to perform operations or calculations. The type of argument is specific to the function or method. Common arguments include numbers, text, cell references, and names.
The likelihood of a computer system or device continuing to function over a given period of time and under specified conditions.
A set of individual strokes in the Unicode Standard used to compose Chinese/Japanese/Korean (CJK) ideographs.
An excerpt from the body of a story that is used as a graphic element in order to call attention to an important aspect of the topic under discussion.
A key on IBM PC and compatible keyboards that normally causes the computer to send a character-based “picture” of the screen contents to the printer.
A letter, number, punctuation mark, or other symbol.
The agreed-upon method for handling shipping costs. Freight terms identify the party responsible for the payment of freight charges.
In I/O operations, to prevent execution of a thread.
A language for querying and manipulating data in multidimensional objects (OLAP cubes).
To halt a process or action, typically without restoring the prior state.
A tool that converts Visual Basic for Applications macros that are opened or saved in a previous format.

The electronic circuit in a computer that generates a steady stream of timing pulses--the digital signals that synchronize every operation. The system clock signal is precisely set by a quartz crystal, typically at a specific frequency between 1 and 50 megahertz. The clock rate of a computer is one of the prime determinants of its overall processing speed, and it can go as high as the other components of the computer allow.

The electronic circuit in a computer that generates a steady stream of timing pulses--the digital signals that synchronize every operation. The system clock signal is precisely set by a quartz crystal, typically at a specific frequency between 1 and 50 megahertz. The clock rate of a computer is one of the prime determinants of its overall processing speed, and it can go as high as the other components of the computer allow.
The incidental cost of product acquisition or product delivery.
A mail message that is targeted toward specific users that meet the specific requirements of a marketing campaign.

A component of a scroll bar that indicates the relative position (and optionally the proportion) of the visible information relative to the entire amount of information. The user can drag the scroll box to view areas of information not currently visible.
The time that an asset will provide a benefit to the business.
A telephone number that points to a hunt group and is the access number for calls that are routed to Unified Messaging servers.
The … character. Can also be represented by entering three dots with no spaces in between (...). Used to convey incompleteness.
The process of producing copies of documents, publications, or images in high volume.

A report to the U.S. Internal Revenue Service (IRS) on a 1099 form. A 1099 form is used to report non-employee income and is filed on a calendar year basis. The IRS produces various types of 1099 forms, including Dividend (1099-DIV), Interest (1099-INT), Miscellaneous (1099-MISC), and Retirement (1099-R).
Pertaining to Microsoft software which is published by Microsoft, properly licensed, and fully supported by Microsoft or a trusted partner.

A hierarchical, distributed database that contains mappings of DNS domain names to various types of data, such as IP addresses. DNS enables the location of computers and services by user-friendly names, and it also enables the discovery of other information stored in the database.

A hierarchical, distributed database that contains mappings of DNS domain names to various types of data, such as IP addresses. DNS enables the location of computers and services by user-friendly names, and it also enables the discovery of other information stored in the database.
An account that describes the changes in value reported on a balance sheet.
A proposed standard digital rights management (DRM) markup language which enables users to specify rights and conditions associated with resources, such as digital content or Web services.
A proposed standard digital rights management (DRM) markup language which enables users to specify rights and conditions associated with resources, such as digital content or Web services.
A workbook that is configured to allow multiple users on a network to view and make changes at the same time. Each user who saves the workbook sees the changes that are made by other users.
Within the borders of one's own country/region.
A wizard that allows third-party developers to achieve the same look in their dialog boxes as Aero.
The process of running a management agent that imports data from a connected data source into the connector space, and then immediately stopping the run.
A grouping of properties presented as a tabbed page of a property sheet.
A classifier that characterizes the magnitude or extent of a quantifiable property of an object or activity.
A fixed installment payment that is agreed to in a payment plan.

The World Wide Web Consortium (W3C) standard language used for creating XML schema documents. The XML schema contains two parts: a set of predefined types (for example, string, dateTime, decimal), and an XML language for defining new types (for example, complexType, minOccurs, element).

The use of the Internet Protocol (IP) for transmitting voice communications. VoIP delivers digitized audio in packet form and can be used to transmit over intranets, extranets, and the Internet. It is essentially an inexpensive alternative to traditional telephone communication over the circuit-switched Public Switched Telephone Network (PSTN). VoIP covers computer-to-computer, computer-to-telephone, and telephone-based communications. For the sake of compatibility and interoperability, a group called the VoIP Forum promotes product development based on the ITU-T H.323 standard to transmit multimedia over the Internet.
The maximum amount on a sales document that an approver is allowed to approve.

An array (arrangement of items) in which many of the entries are identical, commonly zero. It is not possible to define precisely when an array is sparse, but it is clear that at some point, usually when about one-third of the array consists of identical entries, it becomes worthwhile to redefine the array.
Text that has a carriage return (hard return) at the end of it, such as when you press ENTER. Each item in a bulleted or numbered list is a paragraph; a title or subtitle is also a paragraph.
A non-delivery notification that is sent to an e-mail sender when a message cannot be delivered to the intended recipient either temporarily or permanently.
In word processing, a string of characters displayed or printed in a single horizontal row.

A hidden item that contains information about an event sink, information about what events will trigger the event sink, and options that tell when or under what conditions the event sink will be triggered. The event registration item is created in the same folder that is being monitored for events.

The process of viewing and updating the actual progress of tasks so that you can see progress across time, evaluate slippage of tasks, compare scheduled or baseline data to actual data, and check the completion percentage of tasks and your project.
A trademarked name owned by Microsoft Corporation for a high-level, visual-programming version of Basic. Visual Basic was designed for building Windows-based applications.
A line added to a chart that makes it easier to view and evaluate data. Gridlines extend from the tick marks on an axis across the plot area.

A type of program consisting of a set of instructions to an application or tool program. A script usually expresses instructions by using the application`s or tool`s rules and syntax, combined with simple control structures such as loops and if/then expressions.
The action of pressing and releasing one of the mouse buttons.
A transaction that is recorded in a profit and loss account by an expense transaction.

An expansion card or other device used to provide network access to a computer or other device, such as a printer. Mediates between the computer and physical media, such as cabling, over which transmissions travel.
The planned minimum inventory level.
A set of search conditions that is used to find data. Comparison criteria can be a series of characters that you want to match, such as "Northwind Traders," or an expression, such as ">300."
To remove part of a document, usually placing it temporarily in memory so that the cut portion can be inserted (pasted) elsewhere.
Pertaining to the remainder after all deductions, charges, or losses are subtracted from a total.
Checks the data in a field as it is entered. It sets limits or conditions on what can be entered.
For automatic subtotals and worksheet outlines, all rows or columns that summarize detail data. Summary data usually is adjacent to and below the detail data.
Descriptive text that is associated with a piece of content, such as an image.
A property of a field that defines the kinds of data the field can store.
A form of storage characterized by high capacity (roughly 650 MB) and the use of laser optics instead of magnetic means for reading data.
A form of storage characterized by high capacity (roughly 650 MB) and the use of laser optics instead of magnetic means for reading data.
A navigable view of the element objects in an application model.
A navigable view of the element objects in an application model.
To delay a reminder or alarm by a specified time.
To make resources, such as folders and printers, available to others.
A device that reacts or responds to requests or events.
A method for applying estimates on fixed-price projects and investment projects.
A control you place on a form or report to contain an unbound object.
When a relative link is based on a path you specify (the first part of the path that is shared by the file containing the hyperlink and the destination file), that path is the hyperlink base.
To execute a group of statements repeatedly.
To change a system or a data file to make it more current.

An individual value plotted in a chart and represented together with other data points by bars, columns, lines, pie or doughnut slices, dots, and various other shapes called data markers. Data markers of the same color constitute a data series.

An individual value plotted in a chart and represented together with other data points by bars, columns, lines, pie or doughnut slices, dots, and various other shapes called data markers. Data markers of the same color constitute a data series.

In computing, any device in or on which information can be kept. Microcomputers have two main types of storage: random access memory (RAM) and disk drives and other external storage media. Other types of storage include read-only memory (ROM) and buffers.
A Microsoft Office Web application that provides secure access to e-mail, personal calendar, group scheduling, and collaboration applications on Microsoft Exchange Server with only a Web browser.
A Microsoft Office Web application that provides secure access to e-mail, personal calendar, group scheduling, and collaboration applications on Microsoft Exchange Server with only a Web browser.
A purchase order invoice that is created from an intercompany purchase order and posted to an intercompany account.
A property that defines valid input values for a field or record in a table, or a control on a form.
Able to be both read from and written to.
In an Active Directory forest, a server that contains a writable copy of the Active Directory database, participates in Active Directory replication, and controls access to network resources.
In an Active Directory forest, a server that contains a writable copy of the Active Directory database, participates in Active Directory replication, and controls access to network resources.

A Microsoft Office Word document that contains hyperlinks to another location. You can use hyperlinks to go to another location in the same document or to another file on your hard disk, your network, an intranet, or the Internet.

The process of validating software with the manufacturer. Activation confirms the genuine status of a product and that the product key has not been compromised. It establishes a relationship between the software’s product key and a particular installation of that software on a device.
Expressed as n! (n factorial), the result of multiplying the successive integers from 1 through n; n! equals n x (n - 1) x (n - 2) x ... x 1.
The | character.
The | character.
A self-contained unit of the manufacturing process, or an entire plant.
A journal transaction that is posted to a bridging account.

Software that enables a program to work with the user (the user interface, which can be a command-line interface, menu-driven, or a graphical user interface), with another program such as the operating system, or with the computer's hardware.
The = character.
The ability for two or more software applications to work together with little effort from the user.
A feature of Windows that checks for problems associated with network connections.
A feature of Windows that checks for problems associated with network connections.
One of the presets for 3D rotation effects. When selected, specifies that the object will be rotated off-axis.
When referring to software, to load the program and installation files onto your computer or device so that the program runs correctly.
A symbolic value used in place of a real value that is unknown or unavailable at the current time, or that is not displayed for security reasons.

Capable of using or being displayed on the full area of a display screen. Applications running in windowing environments, although they might use the entire area of the screen, commonly allocate different areas to different windows, any of which can be enlarged to fill the entire screen.

To make a device, component, or feature nonfunctional. For example, if you disable a device in a hardware configuration, you cannot use the device when your computer uses that hardware configuration. Disabling a device frees the resources that were allocated to the device.

To make a device, component, or feature nonfunctional. For example, if you disable a device in a hardware configuration, you cannot use the device when your computer uses that hardware configuration. Disabling a device frees the resources that were allocated to the device.
A feature that allows users to check and remove personal and other sensitive information from a document.
A round, flat piece of nonmagnetic, shiny metal encased in a plastic coating, designed to be read from and written to by optical (laser) technology.
An organizational structure in which employees report to multiple managers for different purposes, such as to one manager for administrative purposes and to another for project purposes.
To break input into smaller chunks so that a program can act upon the information.

A device used to store information. There are two types of disks. Hard disks are permanent and installed into your computer. Floppy disks are portable and can be inserted into and removed from a floppy disk drive.

The computer that you are currently logged on to as a user. More generally, a local computer is a computer that you can access directly without using a communications line or a communications device, such as a network adapter or a modem.
To put into operation or to use.
A control designed to contain content such as placeholder or sample text or images that is updated by the user, or pre-defined lists of items from which users can select.
Pertaining to an operation or feature that involves moving objects on the screen with a mouse, a similar input device or a eventually a finger.
A log backup taken from a possibly damaged database to capture the log that has not yet been backed up. A tail-log backup is taken after a failure in order to prevent work loss.
A window which displays a particular message for the user.
A control that allows users to digitally sign a form or document.
A characteristic word, phrase, or code that is used to conduct sorting or searching operations.
To enter numbers on a telephone or mobile device in order to make a phone call.
A small picture that represents a file, folder, program, or other object or function.
An area of storage that is formatted with a file system and has a drive letter. The storage can be a floppy disk, a CD or DVD, a hard disk, or another type of disk.
A program that searches for key words in documents, databases, Internet content or other files.
A list of people, groups, or organizations with whom you communicate.
Any combination of keystrokes that can be used to perform a task that would otherwise require a mouse or other pointing device.
A graphical control you can use to display text that a user can't change directly.
A field in the row or column area that contains custom groups as its items.
