A toolbar that is attached to one edge of the program window. When you drag a toolbar below the program title bar or to the left, right, or bottom edge of the window, the toolbar snaps into place on the edge of the program window.
A feature of Internet Explorer in Windows Vista that finds XML feeds on a webpage. User can view the feeds and subscribe to them.

One or more computers that have a connection to the Internet through an external screening router and a connection to the internal network through an interior screening router. Computers that are linked to the perimeter network have limited access to both the Internet and the internal network. This architecture is convenient if multiple hosts require direct Internet access.
A large-format publication, typically with one dimension much larger than the other, that is printed with a symbol, logo, slogan or other message.
A query that copies or changes data.
A language whose characters require ligation or shaping, such as a right-to-left language (Arabic, Persian, Hebrew, and Urdu) or certain South Asian languages.

Free time appears with a clear availability indicator and is seen as available when others view your Calendar. An appointment of zero duration, while visible in the selected block of time when viewing days, shows as free time to others.

A logical entity that enables a server to communicate with an iSCSI device over an Internet Protocol (IP) network. Each iSCSI initiator can have one or more network adapters through which communication is established.
A communication line used for data transfer among the components of a computer system.
To split a message for routing purposes to deliver to multiple recipients.
A potential customer.
A presentation within a presentation in which you group slides in an existing presentation so that you can show that section of the presentation to a particular audience.
The distance between characters in a line of text. Tracking, kerning, and scaling can be used to adjust the space between characters.

In Windows-based computers, a 32-bit value (a bitmask) that specifies the permissions that are assigned in an access control entry (ACE). An access mask is also part of the access request when an object is opened. The access mask in the request is compared to the access mask in each ACE to determine whether or not to grant the request.
A filter effect in Windows Movie Maker.
A set of characters added to the end of a file name that identifies the file type or format.

A component of Exchange transport that processes all incoming messages and determines what to do with the messages based on information about the intended recipients. In Exchange Server 2007, the Edge Transport server uses the categorizer to route the message to the appropriate destination. The Hub Transport server uses the categorizer to expand distribution lists and identify alternate recipients and forwarding addresses. After the categorizer retrieves full information about recipients, it uses that information to apply policies, route the message, and perform content conversion.
A section of a warehouse used for inventory items with similar characteristics, such as an input area for items when they are received in inventory.
In Exchange Server 2007, a function that is used as a condition or exception on a transport rule to determine whether an action should be applied to an e-mail message.
A logical structure that organizes the members of a set into parent-child relationships.
A set of songs and/or albums selected by the customer, from the customer's music library. ​
A hardware device that reads data from and writes data to floppy disks.
A hardware device that reads data from and writes data to floppy disks.
A hardware device that reads data from and writes data to floppy disks.
A detailed report of the transactions and balance of an account.

A product key that is provided to Microsoft customers who choose a Microsoft Volume Licensing program for their organizations and that allows multiple installations of a particular product. The key is assigned to a company or institution intended for their sole use and only for distribution to employees or third parties who are authorized to install and distribute licenses pursuant to the terms of their license agreement.

A product key that is provided to Microsoft customers who choose a Microsoft Volume Licensing program for their organizations and that allows multiple installations of a particular product. The key is assigned to a company or institution intended for their sole use and only for distribution to employees or third parties who are authorized to install and distribute licenses pursuant to the terms of their license agreement.

A product key that is provided to Microsoft customers who choose a Microsoft Volume Licensing program for their organizations and that allows multiple installations of a particular product. The key is assigned to a company or institution intended for their sole use and only for distribution to employees or third parties who are authorized to install and distribute licenses pursuant to the terms of their license agreement.
An order proposal generated by a master scheduling calculation to fulfill a requirement for a purchased item.
A dialog that requires the user to take some action before the focus can switch to another form or dialog box. Dialog boxes and messages are usually modal.
To submit an article in a newsgroup or other online conference or forum. The term is derived from the "posting" of a notice on a physical bulletin board.
A value that is automatically used by a program when the user does not specify an alternative. Defaults are built into a program when a value or option must be assumed for the program to function.
To package and send interface method parameters across thread or process boundaries.
Text that alerts a user to a note or a warning.
To acknowledge an action or the value of some data (e.g. password) by definite assurance.
A handle that supports sizing an object.
A method of scheduling production so that one operation begins at one work center while another operation is still incomplete at another work center.

Placeholder text that shows where specified information from your data source will appear; the elements in a field that generate a field's result. The field code includes the field characters, field type, and instructions.
The part of a sales order or purchase order that applies to the entire order.
One or more special characters used to separate peers in a delimited structure, at any level (fields, records, and so on).
The exchange of electronic documents between two companies, for example, for the purpose of trading.
The exchange of electronic documents between two companies, for example, for the purpose of trading.

A storage platform that provides a single repository for managing multiple types of unstructured information in one infrastructure. The Exchange store combines the features and functionality of the file system, the Web, and a collaboration server (such as Microsoft Exchange) through a single, URL-addressable location for storing, accessing, and managing information, as well as building and running applications. The Exchange store is also known as the Web Storage System.
A descriptive or user-friendly label for a control or object, displayed on the screen. The display name may differ from the internal name.
A modeless secondary window that displays a toolbar or other choices, such as colors or patterns.
A selection of two or more cells or ranges that don't touch each other.
A procedure for determining the resource capacity requirements that meet the demand of future output during specific time periods.
A set of slides that are imported or created for display in a meeting.

A website from Microsoft which provides updates (patches and fixes) for multiple Microsoft products in one place, including Windows operating system software and Windows-based hardware, Microsoft Office system, Microsoft SQL Server, and Microsoft Exchange Server.
A standard set of formats and procedures that enable computers to exchange information.
An entry to a company account to record a business transaction.
A keyboard key that is used in conjunction with another key to produce some special feature or function and is typically marked with the letters Alt.

The smallest unit of information handled by a computer or device. One bit expresses a 1 or a 0 in a binary numeral, or a true or false logical condition. A group of 8 bits makes up a byte, which can represent many types of information, such as a letter of the alphabet, a decimal digit, or other character.

The smallest unit of information handled by a computer or device. One bit expresses a 1 or a 0 in a binary numeral, or a true or false logical condition. A group of 8 bits makes up a byte, which can represent many types of information, such as a letter of the alphabet, a decimal digit, or other character.
A file (or component within another file) that contains Automation standard descriptions of exposed objects, properties, and methods.
A managed software component that monitors events and performance pertaining to a specific application component, and transmits observations to a host application for display, action, or reporting.
A designation that identifies a document's purpose.

An integral Windows component that supports building, deploying, and running the next generation of applications and XML Web services. It provides a highly productive, standards-based, multilanguage environment for integrating existing investments with next generation applications and services, as well as the agility to solve the challenges of deployment and operation of Internet-scale applications. The .NET Framework consists of three main parts: the common language runtime, a hierarchical set of unified class libraries, and a componentized version of ASP called ASP.NET.
A data type that stores either a 1 or 0 value. Integer values other than 1 or 0 are accepted, but they are always interpreted as 1.
A measurement used for high-capacity data storage. One terabyte equals 240, or 1,099,511,627,776, bytes, although it is commonly interpreted as simply one trillion bytes.
A measurement used for high-capacity data storage. One terabyte equals 240, or 1,099,511,627,776, bytes, although it is commonly interpreted as simply one trillion bytes.
A keyboard key that, when pressed (and held), changes the actions of ordinary input.
To transfer a copy of a file from a remote device to a requesting device by means of a modem or network.
The third axis in a three-dimensional coordinate system, used in computer graphics to represent depth.
The third axis in a three-dimensional coordinate system, used in computer graphics to represent depth.
A technology that uses multidimensional structures to provide rapid access to data for analysis. The source data for OLAP is commonly stored in data warehouses in a relational database.
A technology that uses multidimensional structures to provide rapid access to data for analysis. The source data for OLAP is commonly stored in data warehouses in a relational database.
To become mature or past due, as in a mature account or a past due account.

A slide view or page on which you define formatting for all slides or pages in your presentation. Each presentation has a master for each key component: slides, title slides, speaker's notes, and audience handouts.
The sequence in which configuration groups are selected during the production process.
A feature that allows various mathematical symbols to be entered using the keyboard.
A reusable piece of content, formatting information or other document parts that are stored in galleries.
A concrete implementation of one or more COM interfaces. COM objects are instances of COM classes.
An accounting entry that balances a debit with a credit or a credit with a debit.
Revenue from an hour, expense, fee, or item transaction.
An implementation of the Internet Message Format defined by RFC2822. A message item is stored in the Exchange store.
An alert that is shown to prompt the user to agree to the action being taken.
An account in the general ledger that records financial transactions, balances, or totals that pertain to assets, liabilities, revenues, expenses, and owner equity.
A document used to record payments and deposits received from customers.
A logical tree structure that organizes the members of a dimension such that each member has one parent member and zero or more child members.
A visual output device aimed at displaying various type of information.
To adjust precisely for a particular function.
A feature that provides Web-based applications in a central location to help businesses manage sales, customer relationships, projects, employees, and company functions.
The capability of a resource (worker, machine, work center, plant, or organization) to produce output within a specified period of time without exceeding the available capacity.
The capability of a resource (worker, machine, work center, plant, or organization) to produce output within a specified period of time without exceeding the available capacity.
To make data ready and available for subsequent distribution and deployment in a server environment.
A report that lists the balances of ledger accounts for a specified time period.
To make a chart sheet or worksheet the active, or selected, sheet. The sheet that you activate determines which menu bar and toolbars are displayed.
An external bus that supports Plug and Play installation, which enables you to connect and disconnect devices without shutting down or restarting your computer.
An external bus that supports Plug and Play installation, which enables you to connect and disconnect devices without shutting down or restarting your computer.
A Windows wizard that helps the user import digital video to the computer from digital video cameras and other sources.

The number of colors or levels of gray that can be displayed at one time. The amount or memory in the computer's graphics controller card controls the display. An 8-bit controller can display 256 colors or levels of gray; a 16-bit controller, 64,000 colors; and a 24-bit controller, 16.8 million colors.

A power-saving state that allows the computer or device to quickly resume full-power operation (typically within several seconds) when you want to start working again. All open documents and programs are saved to memory before the computer or device enters the low-power state.
A sequence of activities, actions, or tasks through which documents or items are passed as part of an automated business process.
A method of payment by which a customer pays the freight carrier for goods when they are delivered. The freight carrier then remits the payment to the shipper.
A method of payment by which a customer pays the freight carrier for goods when they are delivered. The freight carrier then remits the payment to the shipper.
A special memory subsystem in which frequently used data values are duplicated for quick access.
A user interface area in which users perform most tasks.
A list of tasks that appears in the Tasks folder and in the TaskPad in Calendar.

A 9-digit number used to identify an entity (company or person) for tax reporting purposes in the U.S. There are several different types of tax identification numbers, such as employer identification number (EIN), Social Security number (SSN), individual taxpayer identification number (ITIN), and adopted taxpayer identification number (ATIN).

A 9-digit number used to identify an entity (company or person) for tax reporting purposes in the U.S. There are several different types of tax identification numbers, such as employer identification number (EIN), Social Security number (SSN), individual taxpayer identification number (ITIN), and adopted taxpayer identification number (ATIN).

A 9-digit number used to identify an entity (company or person) for tax reporting purposes in the U.S. There are several different types of tax identification numbers, such as employer identification number (EIN), Social Security number (SSN), individual taxpayer identification number (ITIN), and adopted taxpayer identification number (ATIN).
A word with the same meaning as another in the same language but often with different implications and associations.
During software upgrades, the product that is already installed on the machine, i.e. the version to be upgraded.
To verify, test or control by comparison or examination.

The process an operating system uses to detect and record security-related events, such as an attempt to create, to access, or to delete objects such as files and directories. The records of such events are stored in a file known as a security log, whose contents are available only to those with the proper clearance.
Pertaining to a mixture of characters that are read from left to right and characters that are read from right to left.
Pertaining to a mixture of characters that are read from left to right and characters that are read from right to left.
The protocol within TCP/IP that governs the breakup of data messages into packets to be sent via IP, and the reassembly and verification of the complete messages from packets received by IP.
The protocol within TCP/IP that governs the breakup of data messages into packets to be sent via IP, and the reassembly and verification of the complete messages from packets received by IP.

The file that a linked or embedded object is inserted into, or that data is saved to. The source file contains the information that is used to create the object. When you change information in a destination file, the information is not updated in the source file.

A database repository for information about a computer's configuration. The registry contains information that Windows continually references during operation, such as: profiles for each user; the programs installed on the computer and the types of documents that each can create; property settings for folders and program icons; what hardware exists on the system; which ports are being used. The registry is organized hierarchically as a tree, and it is made up of keys and their subkeys, hives, and entries.
A folder that stores the user's music library.
Placement of an element in the natural HTML flow of a document, but such that its position is offset from the preceding content.
A title animation in Windows Movie Maker.
To join or link.
Items that are physically in stock and available to be used or sold.
Items that are physically in stock and available to be used or sold.
A method of depreciation based on the usage of the asset.
The state of an expression or a variable (for example, when a result can be either true or false, or equal or not equal).
A hierarchical structure consisting of Navision entities and specific Outlook items that they should be mapped to.
A World Wide Web version of Windows Client Help.
A World Wide Web version of Windows Client Help.
The « character.
A type of connector in the form of a rectilinear line that is used for joining two shapes.
A specific configuration of a bill of material (BOM) to include an item. An item can be associated with a number of BOM versions.
A specific configuration of a bill of material (BOM) to include an item. An item can be associated with a number of BOM versions.
The element in an XML document that contains all other elements. It is the top-level element of an XML document and must be the first element in the document.
The element in an XML document that contains all other elements. It is the top-level element of an XML document and must be the first element in the document.

A method used with SCSI and IDE disk drives to translate the cylinder, head, and sector specifications of the drive into addresses that can be used by an enhanced BIOS. LBA is used with drives that are larger than 528MB.

A method used with SCSI and IDE disk drives to translate the cylinder, head, and sector specifications of the drive into addresses that can be used by an enhanced BIOS. LBA is used with drives that are larger than 528MB.
An additional charge, not related to quantity, for an item.
One of two types of hardware that are connected by an RS-232-C serial connection, the other being a Data Terminal Equipment (DTE) device.
One of two types of hardware that are connected by an RS-232-C serial connection, the other being a Data Terminal Equipment (DTE) device.
The name of a category of information in a mail-merge data source. For example, "City," "State," and "PostalCode" are commonly used field names in an address list.
In programming, a value that is given to a variable, either at the beginning of an operation or before an expression is evaluated by a program.
Pertaining to an entire document, file, or program rather than to a restricted segment of it.

A method of delivering digital media across a network in a continuous flow. The digital media is played by client software as it is received. Typically, streaming makes it unnecessary for users to download a file before playing it.
A high-speed Internet connection. Broadband connections are typically 256 kilobytes per second (KBps) or faster. Broadband includes DSL and cable modem service.
A measure of the fineness of detail in an image or text, usually as produced by a monitor or printer.
A form that Australian businesses file to report and pay taxes.
A form that Australian businesses file to report and pay taxes.
To move data from one location to another.

A person responsible for creating and maintaining a World Wide Web site. A webmaster is often responsible for responding to e-mail, ensuring the site is operating properly, creating and updating Web pages, and maintaining the overall structure and design of the site.
A transaction that contains distributions to another company within the same legal entity.
The “ character.
The “ character.
An accounting method that recognizes revenues when they are earned and expenses when they are incurred, regardless of when they are received or paid.
An accounting method that recognizes revenues when they are earned and expenses when they are incurred, regardless of when they are received or paid.

To put back into a stable condition. A computer user may be able to recover lost or damaged data by using a program to search for and salvage whatever information remains in storage. A database may be recovered by restoring its integrity after some problem has damaged it, such as abnormal termination of the database management program.
A semiconductor circuit that contains information that cannot be modified.
A semiconductor circuit that contains information that cannot be modified.
A division between window panes in a split window; the split bar visually separates window panes.
A value or condition that is not consistent with the true, specified, or expected value or condition.
In Calendar, time status and user defined labels are indicated by colors and patterns.
Software that changes browser settings, such as the home page, without adequate consent.

A standard for electronically marking products so that they can be tracked by using radio frequency identification (RFID). An EPC is 96 bits divided into four partitions: header, manager number, object class, and serial number.

A standard for electronically marking products so that they can be tracked by using radio frequency identification (RFID). An EPC is 96 bits divided into four partitions: header, manager number, object class, and serial number.
A standard Windows control that combines the characteristics of a text box with a drop-down list box.
The slide that stores information about the design template applied, including font styles, placeholder sizes and positions, background design, and color schemes.

The core of layered architecture that manages the most basic operations of the operating system and the computer's processor. The kernel schedules different blocks of executing code, called threads, for the processor to keep it as busy as possible and coordinates multiple processors to optimize performance. The kernel also synchronizes activities among Executive-level subcomponents, such as I/O Manager and Process Manager, and handles hardware exceptions and other hardware-dependent functions. The kernel works closely with the hardware abstraction layer.
The format of a file, commonly indicated by its file name extension. The file type indicates which program the file was created in and can be opened with.
A Windows feature that allows users to connect remotely to a computer and access programs, files, and network resources as though they were sitting at the computer.
A view of the workspace that displays the sequence of your clips.
A structured document or template with spaces reserved for entering information and often containing special coding (e.g. to trigger data processing).
The * character. Indicates multiplication in programming languages and also serves as a wildcard character representing one or more characters.
A feature that allows you to send a snapshot of your calendar to someone outside your Exchange organization and allow them to see the data on your calendar and schedule against it.
A group of OneNote sections.
The arrangement of text and graphics on the page of a document.
An entry in a journal.
A self-signed certification authority certificate.
A search method that lets you direct your search using conversational language.
A search method that lets you direct your search using conversational language.
The process of categorizing, by time period, amounts that are due to a company after a given invoice date or bill date, or the number of days the account has been outstanding.

A source document that documents an offer to supply a quantity of products output from project activities for a specified price and by a specified date in response to a request for quotation in a sales process.
A feature that allows you to run a presentation over the Web. The presentation is saved in HTML format and can contain audio and video. It can also be recorded and saved to be viewed later.

The protocol that improves the security of data communication by using a combination of data encryption, digital certificates, and public key cryptography. SSL enables authentication and increases data integrity and privacy over networks. SSL does not provide authorization or nonrepudiation.

The protocol that improves the security of data communication by using a combination of data encryption, digital certificates, and public key cryptography. SSL enables authentication and increases data integrity and privacy over networks. SSL does not provide authorization or nonrepudiation.
A subproduction order that is created based on the main production order.

To add a special visual or sound effect to text or an object. For example, you can have your text bullet points fly in from the left, one word at a time, or hear the sound of applause when a picture is uncovered.
A series of business activities that when completed will fulfill a high-level objective.
A connection that specifies the name, type, location, and, optionally, other information about a database file or server.
A combination of any of the character formatting options identified by a style name.
The value of a fixed asset calculated as the difference between the original cost of the fixed asset minus its accumulated depreciations.
The value of a fixed asset calculated as the difference between the original cost of the fixed asset minus its accumulated depreciations.
The " character.

The process of finalizing a purchase on a website. For example, when customers shop on your website, they may select several items and save them in their shopping basket. When they have finished shopping, they click on a checkout link or graphical button that takes them to an online form where they enter their name, billing address, payment type, and shipping information.

A menu that contains commands you can use to manipulate a window or close a program. You click the program icon at the left of the title bar to open this menu. The context menu of a window replaces this menu.

The area in the Navigation Pane that contains shortcuts and shortcut groups. It can be accessed by using the Shortcuts button at the bottom of the Navigation Pane. Click a group in the Shortcuts pane to show the shortcuts in the group.
In information processing, fixed or predetermined. For example, a static memory buffer remains invariant in size throughout program execution.
A graphic representation of trends in data series, such as a line sloping upward to represent increased sales over a period of months.

The underlying or original style on which other styles in a document are dependent. When you change a formatting element of the base style in a document, all other styles that originate from the base style will also reflect the change.
To carry on a real-time conversation with other users by computer or device.
Ready-made art, often appearing as a bitmap or a combination of drawn shapes.
The listing of contents at the beginning of a document or file.
The listing of contents at the beginning of a document or file.
The listing of contents at the beginning of a document or file.
Help that is available to the user while not being connected to or part of a system or network.

A partial or limited version of a software package distributed free of charge for advertising purposes. Demos often consist of animated presentations that describe or demonstrate the program's features.
A part, subassembly, or product that is produced by a manufacturing process or resource.

A menu for a group of ready-made shapes that includes basic shapes, such as rectangles and circles, plus a variety of lines and connectors, block arrows, flowchart symbols, stars and banners, and callouts.
Any combination of keys that must be pressed sequentially.
Any combination of keys that must be pressed sequentially.

To move a document or other data in a window in order to view a particular portion of the document. Scrolling may be controlled by the mouse, arrow keys, or other keys on the keyboard, eventually with one or more fingers.

A Windows program that collects and displays for users the system-level features of the computer, including hardware and software setup and configuration. From Control Panel, users can click individual items to configure system-level features and perform related tasks.

An intermediate location between a "from" warehouse and a "to" warehouse for warehouse transfers. Items in a transit warehouse are in the process of being transferred to a different warehouse (transfer order) and therefore cannot be picked for other orders during transportation.
A typographical unit of measure that is equal in width to the point size of a particular font. For many fonts, this is equal to the width of a capital M, from which the em space takes its name.
A software that was installed on the system without user's consent.
A description for a journal line. Transaction text stays with the journal line until an event causes new transaction text to be added, such as when the transaction is settled.
A standard control that allows a user to select from a fixed set of mutually exclusive choices.
A standard control that allows a user to select from a fixed set of mutually exclusive choices.
The speed at which a modem can transmit data, measured by the number of events, or signal changes, that occur in one second.
Of, pertaining to, or characteristic of communications that take place without the use of interconnecting wires or cables, such as by radio, microwave, or infrared.
Any text string used as a label, such as the name of a procedure or a variable in a program or the name attached to a hard disk or floppy disk.
To move around in a document.
In reference to a computing device or a program, unable to communicate with a primary database or controlling computer.
A party that supplies products to one or more legal entities in exchange for payment.
A commonly used file format for storing contact information. Contacts that use the vCard format are stored as .vcf files.
A series of contiguous processing steps through which one or more messages flow.
A collection of photos in electronic format that have been grouped into a virtual album.

An ad that is served to a user's screen either as a pushed (sent by e-mail) or pulled ad (requested by a user's browser). This includes measurement of responses from an ad delivery system to a user's browser.
An entity entrusted to issue certificates that assert that the recipient individual, computer, or organization requesting the certificate fulfills the conditions of an established policy.
An entity entrusted to issue certificates that assert that the recipient individual, computer, or organization requesting the certificate fulfills the conditions of an established policy.
A feature that automatically adjusts the layout if you insert items that don't fit the original layout. You can undo it using the Automatic Layout Options button.
Pertaining to the state of an object when it is not the focus of a user's input.
Pertaining to tasks that need to be done.
An industry-standard one-way, 128-bit hashing scheme, developed by RSA Data Security, Inc., and used by various Point-to-Point Protocol (PPP) vendors for encrypted authentication.
The cells that you copy when you want to paste data into another location. After you copy cells, a moving border appears around them to indicate that they've been copied.
A number specifying a location in memory where data is stored.
To transfer a file from one location to another. After the file is transferred, there is only one copy of the file, in the new location.
A disk, file, document, or other collection of information from which data is taken or moved.
A disk, file, document, or other collection of information from which data is taken or moved.
An interface implemented in the XML message format for describing the network services offered by the server.
An interface implemented in the XML message format for describing the network services offered by the server.

A device that reads the information stored on a compact disc. A compact disc player contains the optical equipment necessary for reading a disc's contents and the electronic circuitry for interpreting the data as it is read.
An e-mail feature providing feedback to the sender that a message has been read by the recipient.
The amount of memory physically installed on your device (as opposed to on a storage card.)
In object-oriented programming, a reusable basic design structure, consisting of abstract and concrete classes, that assists in building applications.
To reduce the amount of information displayed by hiding from view the subentries within a folder, section or conversation, or a portion of text or other content within a control.
An image that is embedded in a line of text rather than in its own window.
A unit of application logic providing data and services to other applications that can invoke Web protocols.
A one-stop shop for customizing Office deployment and setup behaviors.
A classifier that names categories in an ABC classification that ranks discrete categories of items according to their contribution margin.
Instructions that make hardware work.
A window or menu that presents an array or grid of visual choices to a user for selection.

A group of characters or character bytes handled as a single entity. Computer programs use strings to store and transmit data and commands. Most programming languages consider strings (such as 2674:gstmn) as distinct from numeric values (such as 470924).
An infotip for the button on the phone and video controls that ends the conversation.

A connection between multiple tables where records from related fields that match are combined and shown as one record. Records that don't match may be included or excluded, depending on the type of join.
A chart that uses two or more chart types to emphasize that the chart contains different kinds of information, often with different y axes.
Done by positioning the pointer over an item and pressing the left mouse button once.
A user who creates or edits a document.
A character that is entered by pressing the SPACEBAR on the keyboard and that typically appears on the screen as a blank space.
A sign or symbol that specifies the type of calculation to perform within an expression. There are mathematical, comparison, logical, and reference operators.
To configure settings to restrict access to or permissions for a file or specific elements within a file.
A program, routine, or process that performs a specific system function to support other programs.

The degree of difference between light and dark extremes of color on a monitor, device screen, or printed output, or between the darkest and lightest areas in a photo. The greater the difference, the higher the contrast.
A collection of users, computers, contacts, and other groups that is used only for e-mail distribution, and addressed as a single recipient.
A collection of users, computers, contacts, and other groups that is used only for e-mail distribution, and addressed as a single recipient.
A collection of users, computers, contacts, and other groups that is used only for e-mail distribution, and addressed as a single recipient.
The procedures involved in preparing a software program or application to operate within a computer or mobile device.
An area in the Outlook Calendar module where users can display the tasks and other items assigned to that day (or week).
A wizard that guides the user through installing a printer on their network.

The name given by an administrator to a collection of networked computers that share a common directory. Part of the DNS naming structure, domain names consist of a sequence of name labels separated by periods.
The only member of the replica set in which you can make changes to the database structure that can be propagated to other replicas.
A physical card that represents a specific value or amount of service for which the user has paid in advance.
A folder on another computer that has been made available for other people to use on the network.
A smart card that stores a subscriber's personal identifier, billing information, and data.
A smart card that stores a subscriber's personal identifier, billing information, and data.
A supported source of data that can be modeled by Business Connectivity Services, such as a database, Web service, or custom .NET Framework assembly.
A company that provides telephone and other communications services to consumers.
A company that provides telephone and other communications services to consumers.
A Movie Maker tool that helps users quickly create a movie by analyzing the video, pictures, and music that a user selects, and then combining those to create a movie.
An object that enables user interaction or input, often to initiate an action, display information, or set values.

A link to any item accessible on your computer or on a network, such as a program or application, file, folder, disk drive, printer, or another computer. You can put shortcuts in various areas, such as on the desktop, on the Start menu, or in specific folders.
A location or selection of text in a file that you name for reference purposes. Bookmarks identify a location within your file that you can later refer or link to.
A location or selection of text in a file that you name for reference purposes. Bookmarks identify a location within your file that you can later refer or link to.
The collection of custom properties for a shape.
The part of queue time spent waiting for the next operation.
A letter that serves to introduce accompanying documents to the recipient. Often refers to a letter sent with a resume when applying for a job.

A member of the TCP/IP suite of protocols used to distribute network news messages to NNTP servers and clients (newsreaders) on the Internet. NNTP is designed so that news articles are stored on a server in a central database, thus enabling a user to select specific items to read.

A member of the TCP/IP suite of protocols used to distribute network news messages to NNTP servers and clients (newsreaders) on the Internet. NNTP is designed so that news articles are stored on a server in a central database, thus enabling a user to select specific items to read.
A list of the components and subassemblies needed to build one unit of a product. A bill of materials also shows quantities for each component.
A list of the components and subassemblies needed to build one unit of a product. A bill of materials also shows quantities for each component.

An application programming interface (API) that allows users and applications high-level access to data objects in Exchange. CDO defines the concept of different object classes, including messages, posts, appointments, and tasks.

An application programming interface (API) that allows users and applications high-level access to data objects in Exchange. CDO defines the concept of different object classes, including messages, posts, appointments, and tasks.
A software routine that executes in response to an event.

A field that is assigned to a page orientation in a PivotTable or PivotChart report. You can either display a summary of all items in a page field, or display one item at a time, which filters out the data for all other items.
The visible line around the edge of an object. For example, the four lines of a rectangle that comprise its border.
A field that is assigned a category orientation in a PivotChart report. In a chart, categories usually appear on the x-axis, or horizontal axis, of the chart.

A state in which your computer consumes less power when it is idle, but remains available for immediate use. While your computer is on standby, information in computer memory is not saved on your hard disk. If there is an interruption in power, the information in memory is lost.

A gallery for text and graphics, such as a standard contract clause, that can be used multiple times in one or more documents. Each selection of text or graphics is recorded as an AutoText entry and assigned a unique name. It is visible in Quick Parts and the Building Blocks Organizer.

A search feature associated with folders and programs that begins to display results as soon as a keyword is entered. When you enter text, files in the current view are automatically filtered to show only those that match what you typed.

A search feature associated with folders and programs that begins to display results as soon as a keyword is entered. When you enter text, files in the current view are automatically filtered to show only those that match what you typed.

A search feature associated with folders and programs that begins to display results as soon as a keyword is entered. When you enter text, files in the current view are automatically filtered to show only those that match what you typed.
A Control Panel icon in Windows Vista that takes user to the Power Options dialog box where the user can manage the battery life settings.
A parameter in the Perlin Noise function which controls how fast the vector field is changing.

The verification that the XML of a procedure conforms to the provisioning schema of Microsoft Provisioning Framework (MPF). This schema contains the generic XML elements and attributes available to invoke specific provisioning functionality.
To stop the operation of a program or execution of a command temporarily.
Information regarding the availability of a user.
The point at which one line ends and another begins.
To make easier; to eliminate unnecessary steps.
An item on the shortcut menu that adds a selected person to the user's Contacts list.
To manipulate an interface element, such as a toolbar or panel, in order to align it with the edge of another interface element, typically a window or pane.
An error in the grammatical structure of the code or expression.
When referring to hardware, to physically connect the device to your computer, to load device drivers onto your computer, and to configure device properties and settings.

An address book that is automatically created from contacts in the Contacts folder. The contacts can be people inside and outside of your organization. When you update your contacts, the Outlook Address Book is updated as well.
In information processing, an operation performed by the computer at hand rather than by a remote computer.
In line and area charts, lines that extend from a data point to the category (x) axis. Useful in area charts to clarify where one data marker ends and the next begins.
A tax on the import, export, or use and consumption of goods.

Any device capable of processing information to produce a desired result. No matter how large or small they are, computers typically perform their work in three well-defined steps: (1) accepting input, (2) processing the input according to predefined rules (programs), and (3) producing output. There are several ways to categorize computers, including class (ranging from microcomputers to supercomputers), generation (first through fifth generation), and mode of processing (analog versus digital).
A source document that documents an interest payment obligation.
An object that can logically contain other objects. For example, a folder is a container object.
A user-defined classification of supplementary items that have similar characterisitcs.
A menu that is related to the active window or item, accessible by right-clicking the mouse.
A menu that is related to the active window or item, accessible by right-clicking the mouse.
A menu that is related to the active window or item, accessible by right-clicking the mouse.
A menu that is related to the active window or item, accessible by right-clicking the mouse.
A modal pop-up form you create to ask the user for additional information or to display a message.
A file that contains a digital code that makes it possible to seal messages or to add a digital signature to messages. This file can be stored on a 3.5-inch disk or on your computer's hard disk.
The process of taking a single-table database and breaking it into a set of smaller, related tables, with each table focused on a single topic or grouping of information.
A step in the process of manufacturing an item.
A line of characters that is read by special character recognition equipment and translated into computer text.
A line of characters that is read by special character recognition equipment and translated into computer text.
An icon or a warning message that appears when an item quantity, lot number, or serial number is already reserved or otherwise specified for other documents.

In relational database management systems, a logical table created through the specification of one or more relational operations on one or more tables. A view is equivalent to a divided relation in the relational model.
A technique for converting a color in one color space to another color space. Typically, this conversion is from YUV colors from a video source to RGB for display.
To provide or give.

A character used to align lines and columns on screen and in print. Although a tab is visually indistinguishable from a series of blank spaces in most programs, the tab character and the space character are different to a computer. A tab is a single character and therefore can be added, deleted, or overtyped with a single keystroke.

In a shared file, information that is maintained about changes made in past editing sessions. The information includes the name of the person who made each change, when the change was made, and what data was changed.

The normalized value that is assigned to an e-mail message. This value indicates, based on the characteristics of the message, such as the content, message header, and so forth, the likelihood that the message is spam. This value is persisted with the message when the message is sent to other Exchange servers.

The normalized value that is assigned to an e-mail message. This value indicates, based on the characteristics of the message, such as the content, message header, and so forth, the likelihood that the message is spam. This value is persisted with the message when the message is sent to other Exchange servers.
A portion of a software window bounded by and separated from other portions by vertical or horizontal bars and having a separate function.
In an organization chart, a shape that is placed below and connected to a superior (or manager) shape.

An (API) that is provided as part of Microsoft Windows. CryptoAPI provides a set of functions that allow applications to encrypt or digitally sign data in a flexible manner while providing protection for the user's sensitive private key data. Actual cryptographic operations are performed by independent modules known as (CSPs).

An (API) that is provided as part of Microsoft Windows. CryptoAPI provides a set of functions that allow applications to encrypt or digitally sign data in a flexible manner while providing protection for the user's sensitive private key data. Actual cryptographic operations are performed by independent modules known as (CSPs).

An (API) that is provided as part of Microsoft Windows. CryptoAPI provides a set of functions that allow applications to encrypt or digitally sign data in a flexible manner while providing protection for the user's sensitive private key data. Actual cryptographic operations are performed by independent modules known as (CSPs).
A special control added to a window, typically adjacent to the scroll bar, that allows a user to split a window or adjust a window split.
The process of establishing predictable behavior in a device.
In Internet Explorer, a set of tabs you can store in your Favorites or as Home Page to reopen all tabs in the set in one go.
A Microsoft Windows multimedia file format for sound and videos that uses the Microsoft Resource Interchange File Format (RIFF) specification.
A Microsoft Windows multimedia file format for sound and videos that uses the Microsoft Resource Interchange File Format (RIFF) specification.
A Web Storage System content class defines the intent or purpose of an item along with the names of properties that are intended for items in this class.
A status notification that the device is in the process of dialing a phone number.
A visual effect that imparts a quality of translucency to windows.
A visual effect that imparts a quality of translucency to windows.
The distance or period of time between a specified start point and a specified end point. For example, the length of an audio or video clip is usually measured in minutes and seconds.

Binding (converting symbolic addresses in the program to storage-related addresses) that occurs during program execution. The term often refers to object-oriented applications that determine, during run time, which software routines to call for particular data objects.
An individual item that is a component of a kit.
To store frequently used data values in a special memory subsystem for quick access.
To add new text, objects or cells without overwriting existing data.
Pertaining to characters that are evenly slanted to the right or in the direction of text flow.
An action or occurrence to which a program might respond. Examples include state changes, data transfers, key presses, and mouse movements.
An action or occurrence to which a program might respond. Examples include state changes, data transfers, key presses, and mouse movements.
The register of debit and credit entries classified using accounts listed in a chart of accounts.
The register of debit and credit entries classified using accounts listed in a chart of accounts.
The process of detecting and splitting video content into separate clips. Clips are created by Windows Movie Maker when there is a significant change from one frame to another.
The value of an asset as calculated by the acquisition price plus or minus any adjustments (acquisition or value) minus any depreciation previously taken.
A real-time communication session between two or more users. A session can involve IM, video, or audio.

An industry-standard Internet tunneling protocol that provides encapsulation for sending Point-to-Point Protocol (PPP) frames across packet-oriented media. For IP networks, L2TP traffic is sent as User Datagram Protocol (UDP) messages. In Microsoft operating systems, L2TP is used in conjunction with Internet Protocol security (IPSec) as a virtual private network (VPN) technology to provide remote access or router-to-router VPN connections. L2TP is described in RFC 2661.

An industry-standard Internet tunneling protocol that provides encapsulation for sending Point-to-Point Protocol (PPP) frames across packet-oriented media. For IP networks, L2TP traffic is sent as User Datagram Protocol (UDP) messages. In Microsoft operating systems, L2TP is used in conjunction with Internet Protocol security (IPSec) as a virtual private network (VPN) technology to provide remote access or router-to-router VPN connections. L2TP is described in RFC 2661.
An entity that provides goods and/or services to others.
The part of queue time spent waiting for the current operation to begin.
The speed at which a modem transmits data.

The path to an object, document, file, page, or other destination. An address can be a URL (Web address) or a UNC path (network address), and can include a specific location within a file, such as a bookmark within a document or a cell range within a spreadsheet.
A division of quantity established in calibrated or normative systems of measurement.
An area within a shape that can contain text.
A government authority's legal claim to the assets of a legal entity.
A virtual folder that displays items based on specified search criteria.
Data that consists of characters representing the words and symbols of human speech.
To associate data with a specified location in memory.
An expected loss on a project that is treated as an expense transaction because it is likely that the total project cost will exceed the total project revenue or capitalization limit.
A sequence of values, cell references, names, functions, or operators in a cell that together produce a new value.
Any of the devices on a layered communications network that operate on the same protocol level.
The # character.
A current obligation that is payable within one year.

A hidden file on the hard disk that Windows uses to hold parts of programs and data files that do not fit in memory. The paging file and physical memory, or random access memory (RAM), comprise virtual memory. Windows moves data from the paging file to memory as needed and moves data from memory to the paging file to make room for new data.

A hidden file on the hard disk that Windows uses to hold parts of programs and data files that do not fit in memory. The paging file and physical memory, or random access memory (RAM), comprise virtual memory. Windows moves data from the paging file to memory as needed and moves data from memory to the paging file to make room for new data.

A hidden file on the hard disk that Windows uses to hold parts of programs and data files that do not fit in memory. The paging file and physical memory, or random access memory (RAM), comprise virtual memory. Windows moves data from the paging file to memory as needed and moves data from memory to the paging file to make room for new data.
A list that includes two lists. One list allows you to block top-level domain names, including country codes, and the other list allows you to block a language encoding or character set.

To decompress, or pull out, files from a compressed form. When you extract a file, an uncompressed copy of the file is placed in the folder you specify. The original file remains in the compressed folder. Compressed files frequently have a .zip file name extension.
The mechanism by which payment is provided. Includes cash, check, credit card, wire transfer, etc.
A public place (such as a coffee shop, airport, or hotel) with a wireless network that you can use to connect to the Internet.
A public place (such as a coffee shop, airport, or hotel) with a wireless network that you can use to connect to the Internet.
To go back to a previous state by reversing the effects of one or more commands.
A sequence of 25 letters and numbers. To activate some software, you must enter a product key during the activation process.
In a tree structure, an element that is contained by a parent element. A subordinate element.
In a tree structure, an element that is contained by a parent element. A subordinate element.
A control used on a form, report, or data access page to display or modify data from a table, query, or SQL statement.
To write data (typically a file) to a storage medium.
A collection of contact information for particular individuals, groups or organizations.

An add-in that stores macros, AutoText entries, and custom toolbar, menu, and shortcut key settings that you can use while you work with documents based on any template. By default, the Normal template is a global template.

A messaging architecture that enables multiple applications to interact with multiple messaging systems across a variety of hardware platforms. MAPI is built on the Component Object Model (COM) foundation.

A messaging architecture that enables multiple applications to interact with multiple messaging systems across a variety of hardware platforms. MAPI is built on the Component Object Model (COM) foundation.
The smallest amount of disk space that can be allocated to hold a file.
The smallest amount of disk space that can be allocated to hold a file.
A set of interlinked documents in a hypertext system. The user enters the web through a home page.
A set of interlinked documents in a hypertext system. The user enters the web through a home page.
A set of interlinked documents in a hypertext system. The user enters the web through a home page.
A set of interlinked documents in a hypertext system. The user enters the web through a home page.
A set of interlinked documents in a hypertext system. The user enters the web through a home page.
To minimize the duplication of information in a relational database through effective table design.
The ≥ character.

descripGrp.descrip: A word or phrase that the administrator sets for the Content Filter agent to evaluate the content of an e-mail message and apply appropriate filter processing.

Banner near the top of an open e-mail message, appointment, contact, or task. Tells you if a message has been replied to or forwarded, along with the online status of a contact who is using Instant Messaging.
An interactive utility that guides users through a multi-step, infrequently performed task. Effective wizards reduce the knowledge required to perform the task compared to alternative UIs.
The approximate location of one or more resources, such as a person, computer, printer, or asset, in a space plan.
A special symbol that breaks a column when inserted into a document. It ends the current column and starts the next column.
A Microsoft computer operating system with a command-line interface that is used to control many internal computer functions, such as running programs and organizing and maintaining files.
A Microsoft computer operating system with a command-line interface that is used to control many internal computer functions, such as running programs and organizing and maintaining files.
Arranged in order according to the letters of the alphabet.
The portion of a program with which a user interacts.

A request sent in an e-mail message asking the recipient to complete a task. If the recipient accepts the task, it is added to the recipient's task list, and the recipient becomes the new owner of the task.

A standard international numeric abbreviation for a country or geographical region. A language identifier is a 16-bit value that consists of a primary language identifier and a secondary language identifier.

A standard international numeric abbreviation for a country or geographical region. A language identifier is a 16-bit value that consists of a primary language identifier and a secondary language identifier.

A standard international numeric abbreviation for a country or geographical region. A language identifier is a 16-bit value that consists of a primary language identifier and a secondary language identifier.

A standard international numeric abbreviation for a country or geographical region. A language identifier is a 16-bit value that consists of a primary language identifier and a secondary language identifier.
A type of flowchart that shows the relationship between a business process and the functional units (such as departments) responsible for that process.
A button, option, or other UI element that permanently removes the selected text or objects.
A source document that documents production requirements generated from a production plan.

A set of keystrokes and instructions recorded and saved as a key combination (such as CTRL + X) or file name. When the macro is used, all of the recorded steps are performed automatically. Macros save time by replacing a series of frequently performed steps with a simple key combination or name.
An area in a warehouse where items are stored when they are received in inventory.
An object whose surface contains faces, each of which is described by a simple polygon.
A standard method for sending an HTML document encapsulated with inline graphics, applets, linked documents, and other items referred to in the HTML document.
Memory that is not allocated to any program.
In communications, the process of transferring a copy of a file from a local computer to a remote computer by means of a modem or network.
A location on the horizontal ruler that indicates how far to indent text or where to begin a column of text. The user can move to this location by pressing the TAB key.
A single- or double-digit number associated with telephone numbers, or e-mail or Web addresses, that enables users to quickly access the numbers or addresses.
A single- or double-digit number associated with telephone numbers, or e-mail or Web addresses, that enables users to quickly access the numbers or addresses.

In a Web Parts connection, a server control that sends data to a consumer control. A provider can be a WebPart control or any type of server control, but must be designed to function as a provider. A provider must have a special callback method marked with a ConnectionProviderAttribute attribute in the source code. This method provides data to consumer controls in the form of an interface instance.
An animated border that appears around a worksheet range that has been cut or copied. To cancel a moving border, press ESC.
A unit of data that typically holds a single character, such as a letter, a digit, or a punctuation mark. Some single characters can take up more than one byte.
A list of the items, along with their quantities and locations, that are required to fill a manufacturing order or shipping order.
The ' character (user-typed text).
The ' character (user-typed text).

A set of coordinated graphic elements applied to a document or Web page, or across all pages in a Web site. Themes can consist of designs and color schemes for fonts, link bars, and other page elements.

A mechanism that helps reduce the volume of antivirus scanning that is required across an organization by stamping messages that have been scanned for viruses with metadata that indicates the version of the antivirus software that performed the scan and the result of that scan. This metadata, or "stamp," travels securely with the message as it is routed through different e-mail servers within the organization and is used to determine whether subsequent additional virus scanning on the message can be bypassed.
A message or announcement sent to the user or administrator of a system. The recipient may be a human or an automated notification manager.
Formatting that is applied to cell contents, form controls, Outlook items or other data based on one or more logical conditions.
A technique for filtering records in a form, datasheet, or data access page in which you retrieve only records that contain the selected value.
A fraction that is written vertically with the numerator on the top and the denominator below, with a horizontal fraction bar between them.
A number whose form indicates position in an ordered sequence of items, such as first, third, or twentieth.

Broadly, any device that performs arithmetic operations on numbers. Sophisticated calculators can be programmed for certain functions and can store values in memory, but they differ from computers in several ways: they have a fixed set of commands, they do not recognize text, they cannot retrieve values stored in a data file, and they cannot find and use values generated by a program such as a spreadsheet.
The date that the selling party confirms that the items will ship to a customer or vendor.

Category labels in a chart that, based on worksheet data, are automatically displayed on more than one line in a hierarchy. For example, the heading Produce might appear above a row with headings Tofu, Apples, and Pears.
An implementation of Domain Name System (DNS) written and ported to most available versions of the UNIX operating system. The Internet Software Consortium maintains the BIND software.
The overall layout or pattern of a document.
A person who uses a computer that is not connected to a network. A local user is most likely someone using a computer at home.

A communication mechanism that allows computers to communicate with one another over a network. An RPC consists of a procedure identifier, parameters passed to the procedure, and a value returned to the caller (client computer) after the procedure has executed on the remote system (server computer).
A standard Windows control that combines text box and list box functions.

In a virtual memory system, the address the application uses to reference memory. The kernel and the memory management unit (MMU) translate this address into a physical address before the memory is actually read or written.
The attributes of a cell in a spreadsheet, such as its being alphabetic or numeric, the number of digits, the use of commas, and the use of currency signs.
To rerun a query underlying the active form or datasheet in order to reflect changes to the records, display newly added records, and eliminate deleted records.
A group of settings that affect how a file is printed on the page. Includes paper size and orientation, page margins, headers and footers.
A label that provides additional information about a data marker, which represents a single data point or value that originates from a datasheet cell.

A separate worksheet that lists changes being tracked in a shared workbook, including the name of the person who made the change, when and where it was made, what data was deleted or replaced, and how conflicts were resolved.
A service for making calls outside the "home" service area defined by a service provider.
A software component that enables message exchange through a specific transport.
A software component that enables message exchange through a specific transport.
A feature that allows the user to share items such as documents or folders with other devices on a layered communications network that operate on the same protocol level.
A color model that describes color information in terms of the red (R), green (G), and blue (B) intensities that make up the color.
A specific book used for reporting purposes that contains all depreciation transactions for assets that are valid for that book.
An assessment of music or video content on a scale that corresponds to the user's opinion of the content.

A method for scheduling resources that considers limits to the type of work a work center can perform at a given time. Finite property specifies the type of products or operations to be carried out at the same time at a work center.

A method for scheduling resources that considers limits to the type of work a work center can perform at a given time. Finite property specifies the type of products or operations to be carried out at the same time at a work center.
The string that is used to define how to create an in-country/region number to use when making calls from a dial plan.
The string that is used to define how to create an in-country/region number to use when making calls from a dial plan.
Any combination of operators, constants, literal values, functions, and names of fields (columns), controls, and properties that evaluates to a single value.
In Windows Live Messenger and Windows Live Mail desktop, a video exchange through instant messages between two or more people.
A condition that occurs when an application allocates memory for use but does not free allocated memory when finished.
The button on your pointing device that you use most often for clicking and double-clicking.
The button on your pointing device that you use most often for clicking and double-clicking.
A data unit of 1024 bytes.
A data unit of 1024 bytes.
To enter information by means of the keyboard.
A field that displays all rows, or records, from the underlying record source.
A utility that makes a computer easier to use for people with disabilities. Examples of accessibility aids include screen readers, speech recognition programs, and on-screen keyboards.

Symbols in legends that show the patterns and colors assigned to the data series (or categories) in a chart. Legend keys appear to the left of legend entries. Formatting a legend key also formats the data marker that's associated with it.
A device, such as a disk drive, printer, modem, or joystick, that is connected to a computer and is controlled by the computer's microprocessor.
A device, such as a disk drive, printer, modem, or joystick, that is connected to a computer and is controlled by the computer's microprocessor.
To modify or assemble hardware or software to suit the needs or preferences of the user.
A routable protocol in the TCP/IP protocol suite that is responsible for IP addressing, routing, and the fragmentation and reassembly of IP packets.
A routable protocol in the TCP/IP protocol suite that is responsible for IP addressing, routing, and the fragmentation and reassembly of IP packets.
A keyword or description used to identify groups of related items.
A software program used to display webpages and to navigate the Internet.
A software program used to display webpages and to navigate the Internet.

A directive to an e-mail program to send a complete copy of a given piece of mail to another individual. The use of cc mail addressing, as opposed to directly addressing the mail to a person, generally implies that the recipient is not required to take any action; the message is for informational purposes only. In a cc directive, the fact that this recipient received the mail is printed in the mail header and is thus known to all other recipients.

A directive to an e-mail program to send a complete copy of a given piece of mail to another individual. The use of cc mail addressing, as opposed to directly addressing the mail to a person, generally implies that the recipient is not required to take any action; the message is for informational purposes only. In a cc directive, the fact that this recipient received the mail is printed in the mail header and is thus known to all other recipients.
Pertaining to a process that is performed by a person, rather than automated.
The state in which users fill out forms when working offline.
A device that enables a broadband connection to the Internet by using cable television infrastructure. Access speeds vary greatly, with a maximum throughput of 10 megabits per second (Mbps).
A method of preventing a denial of service attack by limiting the number of requests that can be made to a system.
An unfilled customer order or commitment. A back order is an immediate (or past due) demand against an item whose inventory is insufficient to satisfy the demand.
To eliminate text, a file, or part of a document with the intention of removing the information permanently.
A device that converts analog images (for example, from a television or VCR) into digital images.
A scheduling method that assumes that limited capacity for labor and machines is available.
A scheduling method that assumes that limited capacity for labor and machines is available.
The difference between two values, such as the difference between estimated and actual expenses.
A Control Panel item that allows the user to view saved networks and reconnect to them.
A phone number that subscribers can dial to reach online services.
A 16-byte value generated from the unique identifier on a device, the current date and time, and a sequence number. It is used to identify a particular device, component, user, or session.
A 16-byte value generated from the unique identifier on a device, the current date and time, and a sequence number. It is used to identify a particular device, component, user, or session.
A 16-byte value generated from the unique identifier on a device, the current date and time, and a sequence number. It is used to identify a particular device, component, user, or session.
A 16-byte value generated from the unique identifier on a device, the current date and time, and a sequence number. It is used to identify a particular device, component, user, or session.
A 16-byte value generated from the unique identifier on a device, the current date and time, and a sequence number. It is used to identify a particular device, component, user, or session.
A 16-byte value generated from the unique identifier on a device, the current date and time, and a sequence number. It is used to identify a particular device, component, user, or session.
A 16-byte value generated from the unique identifier on a device, the current date and time, and a sequence number. It is used to identify a particular device, component, user, or session.
A 16-byte value generated from the unique identifier on a device, the current date and time, and a sequence number. It is used to identify a particular device, component, user, or session.

A local area network (LAN) that sends and receives data via radio, infrared optical signaling, or some other technology that does not require a physical connection between individual nodes and the hub. Wireless LANs are often used in office or factory settings where a user must carry a portable computer from place to place.
Editing that occurs within a structured document such as a well-formed XML document.
A Microsoft Exchange Mailbox Assistant that creates managed folders in users' mailboxes and applies managed content settings to them for messaging records management (MRM).
Any feature in the computer system based on older technology for which compatibility continues to be maintained in other system components.
A limitation or a restriction.

A keyboard key, often labeled with both a left-pointing and a right-pointing arrow, that traditionally (as in word processing) is used to insert tab characters into a document. In other applications, such as menu-driven programs, the TAB key is often used to move the on-screen highlight from place to place.
A built-in format that can be applied to a range of data, or to controls and sections in a form or report to change their appearance.

The name by which a user is identified to a computer system or network. During the logon process, the user must enter the username and the correct password. If the system or network is connected to the Internet, the username generally corresponds to the leftmost part of the user's e-mail address (the portion preceding the @ sign, as in username@company.com).
A primary document used in Excel to store and work with data. A worksheet consists of cells that are organized into columns and rows; a worksheet is always stored in a workbook.
A standardized set of best practices and principles for conducting non-clinical laboratory studies.
A standardized set of best practices and principles for conducting non-clinical laboratory studies.
A title animation in Windows Movie Maker.
A symbol, or a series of symbols, compiled by a computer and authorized by an individual to be the legally binding equivalent of the individual's handwritten signature.
A specific action carried out by a computer in the process of executing a program.

A mechanism provided by the common language runtime whereby managed code is granted permissions by security policy and these permissions are enforced, helping to limit the operations that the code will be allowed to perform.
A payment order with reference number in Swiss banking.
The date on which bonds, policies, stock, etc. are issued.
A status displayed when the phone sound volume is set to 0 and vibration is off.
A variety of graphics tablet that uses pressure sensors, rather than the electromagnetics used in more expensive high-resolution tablets, to track the position of a device on its surface.

A group of files that modify Windows features. Package types include service packs, security updates, language packs, and hotfixes. Examples of packages include LanguagePack, Windows Foundation, and FeaturePack.
An area within the Outlook application window that can be enabled to show an overview of the user's schedule, tasks and frequent contacts.

A unique number governments issue to companies and citizens in order to track taxes paid on goods and services. VAT IDs in the European Union contain a country prefix followed by up to 12 digits or characters.
A value, usually a currency amount, that is assigned to goods or to services.

A high-speed, connection-oriented, virtual circuit-based packet switching protocol used to transport many different types of network traffic. ATM packages data in 53-byte, fixed-length cells that can be switched quickly between logical connections on a network.

A high-speed, connection-oriented, virtual circuit-based packet switching protocol used to transport many different types of network traffic. ATM packages data in 53-byte, fixed-length cells that can be switched quickly between logical connections on a network.
To prohibit the use of a document as a contract.

A feature that allows x86-based computers to support more than 4 gigabytes (GB) of physical memory. Up to 64 GB of physical memory can be used as regular 4-kilobyte (KB) pages, and the number of bits that can be used by the kernel to address physical memory can be expanded from 32 to 36.

A feature that allows x86-based computers to support more than 4 gigabytes (GB) of physical memory. Up to 64 GB of physical memory can be used as regular 4-kilobyte (KB) pages, and the number of bits that can be used by the kernel to address physical memory can be expanded from 32 to 36.
A form of statistical analysis used for forecasting. Regression analysis estimates the relationship between variables so that a given variable can be predicted from one or more other variables.
In the Microsoft WOSA (Windows Open System Architecture) structure, an interface providing a common language for Windows applications to gain access to a database on a network.

The name used to represent the same computer on which a TCP/IP message originates. If you access a server-based web site by using http://localhost, the request does not actually go out to the Internet.
The middle part of the main Outlook window that displays the contents of the selected folder.
The document in which you are working.
A title animation in Windows Movie Maker.
