These services help provide uniform platform- and language-independent behavior of managed-code applications.

A legal entity that assumes the role of a vendor that is authorized to supply products to one or more legal entities that are part of the same organization that consolidates the accounts of all of the legal entities.

A quantitative measure of performance that is used to compare the company's products, services, or processes to an external standard. Competitive benchmarks are based on industry best, and process benchmarks are based on best in class.
An access control list that is controlled by the owner of an object and that specifies the access particular users or groups can have to the object.
An access control list that is controlled by the owner of an object and that specifies the access particular users or groups can have to the object.

Part of the integrated Routing and Remote Access service that provides remote networking for telecommuters, mobile workers, and system administrators who monitor and manage servers at multiple branch offices. Users can use Network Connections to dial in to remotely access their networks for services such as file and printer sharing, electronic mail, scheduling, and SQL database access.
A method of real-time communication over the Internet in which a sender types a message to one or more recipients and the recipient immediately receives the message in a chat area.
A method of real-time communication over the Internet in which a sender types a message to one or more recipients and the recipient immediately receives the message in a chat area.
A connection between the user's device and a server that provides access to the Internet, typically through an Internet service provider.
A connection between the user's device and a server that provides access to the Internet, typically through an Internet service provider.

A lightweight protocol designed to make the automated discovery, management, and configuration of iSCSI and Fiber Channel Protocol (FCP) devices on a TCP/IP network easier by providing a common mechanism for initiators and targets to discover one another and for handling zoning and authentication of both targets and initiators.

A lightweight protocol designed to make the automated discovery, management, and configuration of iSCSI and Fiber Channel Protocol (FCP) devices on a TCP/IP network easier by providing a common mechanism for initiators and targets to discover one another and for handling zoning and authentication of both targets and initiators.
A tool that helps you create or edit a formula and also provides information about functions and their arguments.
A tool that helps you create or edit a formula and also provides information about functions and their arguments.
A bill of material that makes up a component of another bill of material.
A bill of material that makes up a component of another bill of material.
The area of the Query window that displays the tables in a query. Each table displays the fields from which you can retrieve data.
In a PivotTable report, the summarized data calculated from the data fields of a source list or table.

A character used to control the format of displayed or printed information, rather than to represent a particular letter, digit, or other special character. The space ( ) is one of the more important nonprinting characters.
A sequence of shades ranging from black through white, used in computer graphics to add detail to images or to represent a color image on a monochrome output device.
To scan a database, a list of files, or the Internet, either for a particular item or for anything that seems to be of interest.
Light that is beyond red in the color spectrum. While the light is not visible to the human eye, infrared transmitters and receivers can send and receive infrared signals.
Someone who visits a Web site and purposefully supplies personal information, such as name, address, and phone number.

A feature that enables records managers to create and manage entries to a “Holds list” such that any document, image, or webpage on that list cannot be deleted, modified, or allowed to expire until the item is removed from the list. The feature is typically used for items that are subject to events such as litigation, audits, or investigations.
A set of files that can be delivered as a unit to a client computer or device for installation.
A Control Panel feature that is used to set restrictions on what traffic is allowed to enter your network from the Internet.
A Web site that impersonates a trustworthy Web site to obtain user's personal or financial information.
A utility that enables the user to locate and open files and folders.
A utility that enables the user to locate and open files and folders.
The number of hours spent waiting for an operation to begin.
Any of the set of words that comprises a given programming language or set of operating-system routines.
The location where text or graphics will be inserted. Also used for text box controls to indicate input focus.
The location where text or graphics will be inserted. Also used for text box controls to indicate input focus.
A company or entity that participates in a business-to-business (B2B) or application-to-application (A2A) data exchange.

A feature that allows a Unified Messaging-enabled user to access their Microsoft Exchange Server mailbox over the telephone. Users can navigate through their mailboxes by using telephone-key or Speech input.
A status that can be applied to blocks of time in a user's Calendar to indicate that the user will be away.
The color against which characters and graphics are displayed.

A button control within a graphical user interface that when clicked remains "down" (appearing to be pressed) until it is clicked again. It can display either text or a picture, and can be standalone or part of an option group.
Pertaining to items that occur repeatedly. For example, an appointment or task that occurs on a regular basis, such as a weekly status meeting or a monthly haircut, can be designated as recurring.
Software that changes settings without adequate consent.
An action query that changes a set of records according to criteria you specify. An update query does not return any records.
A file system used by MS-DOS and Microsoft Windows operating systems to organize and manage files.
A list that includes the e-mail addresses of mailing lists for which you want to be a recipient. Messages sent to such a mailing list and received by you will not be treated as junk e-mail.

A security feature that monitors programs on a computer to determine if they use system memory safely. To do this, DEP software works alone or with compatible microprocessors to mark some memory locations as "non-executable." If a program tries to run code that is malicious or is not from a protected location, DEP closes the program and notifies you.

A security feature that monitors programs on a computer to determine if they use system memory safely. To do this, DEP software works alone or with compatible microprocessors to mark some memory locations as "non-executable." If a program tries to run code that is malicious or is not from a protected location, DEP closes the program and notifies you.
A character that has meaning independent of other characters, or any graphical character that is not a diacritical mark.
One unit of ownership interest in a company.
A program you use to view, print, and electronically mail a snapshot, such as a report snapshot.

A mailbox folder (such as the Inbox folder) that appears in Office Outlook by default and to which messaging records management (MRM) has been applied. The retention and journaling of messages in managed default folders are controlled by managed content settings that are applied to the folder.

A designated server through which Exchange routes all outgoing messages. The smart host then makes the remote connection. If a smart host is designated, the Exchange server only needs to transmit to the smart host, instead of repeatedly contacting the domain until a connection is made.

A designated server through which Exchange routes all outgoing messages. The smart host then makes the remote connection. If a smart host is designated, the Exchange server only needs to transmit to the smart host, instead of repeatedly contacting the domain until a connection is made.
A commitment made by a legal entity to incur a cost when a future obligation comes due.
An order due date, generated by master scheduling, that is based on lead times for all levels of an item.
A type of operations network in which simultaneous operations take place or in which operations overlap, are contingent on each other, or have other complex relationships.
The consistent positioning of text, graphics, and other objects.
A temporary negative quantity of an item, such as may occur when items have been purchased and received but for which a packing slip has not yet been processed.
A return code that begins with E_ or DB_E_ and indicates that the method failed completely and was unable to do any useful work. Usually indicates a programming error.
A virtual shape that contains default formatting properties for new shapes. Each presentation contains one default shape.
The degree to which a product or service executes its specified function.
A window in which you work with queries in Design view, Datasheet view, SQL view, or Print Preview.

In Windows-based systems, a list of access control entries (ACE) that apply to an entire object, a set of the object's properties, or an individual property of an object, and that define the access granted to one or more security principals.

In Windows-based systems, a list of access control entries (ACE) that apply to an entire object, a set of the object's properties, or an individual property of an object, and that define the access granted to one or more security principals.
A printed page that displays author notes beneath the slide that the notes accompany.
A clustered Exchange deployment that uses shared storage and can have multiple active and passive servers (referred to as nodes) dedicated to a clustered mailbox server.
The prescribed sequence for withdrawing the required components from inventory for manufacturing a product.
Free or busy information for internal or federated contacts obtained by Lync or Office Communicator from Microsoft Outlook via a web service.

On a keyboard, the combination of a plastic keycap, a tension mechanism that suspends the keycap but allows it to be pressed down, and an electronic mechanism that records the key press and key release.
To move a call to another phone before the call is answered.
In respect to privacy, an individual's ability to view, modify, and contest the accuracy and completeness of PII collected about him or her. Access is an element of the Fair Information Practices.
An outlined container that displays a markup element, such as a comment or revision, in the margin of a document.
An outlined container that displays a markup element, such as a comment or revision, in the margin of a document.
To activate an application program (especially on the Macintosh) from the operating system's user interface.
A Microsoft web-based service that provides customized accounts to users so that they can select, purchase, download, and update software applicable to Microsoft Windows from multiple retailers.
The original plan for a project, a work package, or an activity.

A list created to apply a hierarchical structure to any list or document. A document can have up to nine levels, and Microsoft Office Word does not apply built-in heading styles to the items in the list.
Header and footer information, or header information only, which encapsulates or precedes document data for transport.
A check to ensure that each unique document is received once and only once.
A forum on the Internet for discussions on a specified range of subjects.
A forum on the Internet for discussions on a specified range of subjects.
Technology that enables rendering operations to be handled by the client.
Technology that enables rendering operations to be handled by the client.
A title animation in Windows Movie Maker.
A software product that acts as a server for one or more services. Typically, a server product would be installed on a server machine (hardware), and provide services to users over the network.
In a DVD or a video, a portion of a title, such as a scene or sequence. A title can contain one or more chapters.

A pane that displays document property information for Word, Excel, and PowerPoint files stored in a WSS library. The pane is displayed below the ribbon and is actually a hosted custom InfoPath form. Information is synced automatically between the document and the WSS library.

A pane that displays document property information for Word, Excel, and PowerPoint files stored in a WSS library. The pane is displayed below the ribbon and is actually a hosted custom InfoPath form. Information is synced automatically between the document and the WSS library.
The smallest executable entity within a programming language.
The smallest executable entity within a programming language.
A method of depreciation in which depreciation amounts are entered manually into a schedule instead of being calculated from a table.
A compact disc containing audio information (as opposed to a CD-ROM containing data and files).
A customer service issue or problem reported by a customer and the activities that customer service representatives use to resolve it.
A customer service issue or problem reported by a customer and the activities that customer service representatives use to resolve it.
A customer service issue or problem reported by a customer and the activities that customer service representatives use to resolve it.
A standard signaling protocol for establishing multi-media communications sessions between two or more users over an IP network.
An internal project for which costs of hours, expenses, and items can be registered, but not capitalized.
A copy of a file that has been saved to a server.
A named storage area on a computer or device containing files and other folders. Folders are used to organize information electronically, the same way actual folders in a filing cabinet do.
Text objects you create with ready-made effects to which you can apply additional formatting options.
A button that directs the user to the Home section of an application.
To prepare a bill of exchange or a promissory note.
The text that forms the major content of a publication. Does not include titles, headlines, pull quotes, and captions, for example.
An account used to post intercompany transactions.
A rectangular control in an application that allows the user to enter or edit text.
A rectangular control in an application that allows the user to enter or edit text.
The practice of reconciling general ledger accounts.
To convert encrypted content back into its original form.
A key in a database table that comes from another table (also know as the "referenced table") and whose values match the primary key (PK) or unique key in the referenced table.
A key in a database table that comes from another table (also know as the "referenced table") and whose values match the primary key (PK) or unique key in the referenced table.
The maximum WIP value that can be posted to an investment project.
A report of payroll allocation amounts.
The use of a capital letter in writing or printing.
A predefined combination of grouped and sorted messages in table view.
A report that summarizes a company's costs, expenses, and revenues for a specific accounting period.
A report that summarizes a company's costs, expenses, and revenues for a specific accounting period.
The amount of owners' investment in a business plus retained earnings.
A temporary endeavor undertaken to meet or exceed stakeholder expectations.
The process of creating, adjusting, issuing, processing, and tracking a quotation from beginning, when customer information is collected, to ending, when the quotation is lost, canceled, or accepted.
The weight of an empty container and packing material, which is deducted from gross weight to determine the weight of the goods.
A high definition optical disc format which uses a smaller focus blue-violet 405 nm laser allowing higher precision and storage density. A competitor to Blu-ray Disc.
A high definition optical disc format which uses a smaller focus blue-violet 405 nm laser allowing higher precision and storage density. A competitor to Blu-ray Disc.
A high definition optical disc format which uses a smaller focus blue-violet 405 nm laser allowing higher precision and storage density. A competitor to Blu-ray Disc.
A high definition optical disc format which uses a smaller focus blue-violet 405 nm laser allowing higher precision and storage density. A competitor to Blu-ray Disc.
An order that is generated to fulfill an item requirement and that cannot be modified as to quantity or time.

The decrease in the value of an asset calculated as the difference in the value of the asset when two economic events occur and when the difference is recognized on the occurrence of the second event as a reduction in wealth.
A dialog box that displays information about an object in the interface.

A data structure that contains security information associated with a protected object. Security descriptors include information about who owns the object, who can access it and in what way, and what types of access are audited.

A technology that allows for ease of creating a new or expanding an existing wireless network. This setup can be done automatically using a USB flash driver or manually through a Wireless Network Setup wizard.
To arrange to receive a product or use a service regularly.

A mailbox server that is installed in a Windows failover cluster. A clustered mailbox server is used in both cluster continuous replication (CCR) and single copy cluster (SCC) configurations. A clustered mailbox server was called an Exchange Virtual Server in previous versions of Exchange Server.
A set of projects that are invoiced from the same invoice proposal.

A set of components and services that enable voice, fax, and e-mail messages to be stored in a user's single mailbox. Users can also access their Microsoft Exchange Server 2007 mailbox from a telephone or a computer.
The component or product that is covered by a service agreement.
A graphic ad that is the full height of a page and normally 120 pixels wide.
A transaction for the acceptance of items into inventory. An inventory receipt increases inventory on hand.
To make a record, file, or other data available in the system.
Waste that occurs during the manufacturing process.
The time it takes for a physical manufacturing operation, excluding setup time, queue time, and move time.
A value multiplied by the base price to calculate a subscription price.
A character that separates items in a list.
The minimum amount of time required for production of an item.
An audible or visual warning signal, generated by a computer, indicating that a threshold has been or is about to be breached.
A limited capacity situation where production is scheduled around existing reservations for work centers. Production begins when capacity becomes available.
A display option of the Windows Control Panel that makes it look and work like it did in previous versions.
In Windows-based systems, a unique value that identifies a user, group, or computer account within an enterprise. Every account is issued a SID when it is created.
In Windows-based systems, a unique value that identifies a user, group, or computer account within an enterprise. Every account is issued a SID when it is created.
In Windows-based systems, a unique value that identifies a user, group, or computer account within an enterprise. Every account is issued a SID when it is created.
To remove the stacked view of windows.
A detailed list of all the jobs for each operation, including setup, process, queue and transportation times.
A file that stores information about a connection to a data source, such as an Access database, spreadsheet, or text file, and that facilitates data source administration.
A file that stores information about a connection to a data source, such as an Access database, spreadsheet, or text file, and that facilitates data source administration.
A method for determining a production schedule by beginning with the date the order is required to be ready and working backward to the date work must begin in order to meet the required due date.
A method for determining a production schedule by beginning with the date the order is required to be ready and working backward to the date work must begin in order to meet the required due date.
An Internet protocol used for sending electronic mail.
To send a production order from the estimation and scheduling stage to the shop floor so that production can begin.
An asset that is cash or easily converted into cash.
A classification of jobs based on the sequence in which they occur, from the time a job enters the work center to the time it leaves the work center.
The process and procedures for handling items that move to and from quarantine.
The date transferred goods are received in a warehouse. Receipt date applies to transfer orders.
A camera for use with a computer to transmit a video picture.
A number of days added to normal procurement time for items to protect against unplanned delays.
The forecasted allocation of the cost of an asset over a period of time for accounting and tax purposes.
A potential sales transaction in process.
A potential sales transaction in process.
Data structures that drivers use to communicate with each other.
Data structures that drivers use to communicate with each other.
A limit, specified as a percentage of quantity ordered, for how much the purchaser will accept over the amount ordered. Overdelivery typically applies to bulk items.
A feature that enables the user to create, manage and apply standardized citations and references in a document.
A receptacle for holding goods to be stored or transported.
A program file used to connect to a particular database. Each database program, such as Access or dBASE, or database management system, such as SQL Server, requires a different driver.
A named entity made up of an XML document and an operation on that document. Web services can be generated from actions.
A feature that allows access to SharePoint documents and sites and documents on shares inside of a corporate network through Outlook Web Access when it is used remotely.
To find.

A single cumulative package composed of one or more files used to address a problem in a product. Hotfixes address a specific customer situation and may not be distributed outside that customer organization.

A single cumulative package composed of one or more files used to address a problem in a product. Hotfixes address a specific customer situation and may not be distributed outside that customer organization.

Components that can be installed on your computer to add commands and functions to Excel. These add-in programs are specific to Excel. Other add-in programs that are available for Excel or Office are Component Object Model (COM) add-ins.
A digital interface specification for delivering digital content and connecting consumer electronic devices.
A digital interface specification for delivering digital content and connecting consumer electronic devices.
A digital interface specification for delivering digital content and connecting consumer electronic devices.

A person, inside or outside your organization, for whom you have created an entry where you can save several types of information, such as street and e-mail addresses, telephone and fax numbers, and Web page URLs.
A display setting that holds up to 256 specific color entries. Any color palette attached to a picture is by definition an 8-bit palette.
The device that communicates between your software program and your printer.

An object created with one program and embedded into a document created by another. Embedding the object, rather than simply inserting or pasting it, ensures that the object retains its original format. If you double-click the embedded object, you can edit it with the toolbars and menus from the program used to create it.
The mechanism used to help a caller differentiate between users with names that match the touch-tone or speech input.
A record of the time that a document was created and modified.

Antispyware software included in Windows that can prevent other software from displaying advertisements (such as pop-up ads), collect information about you, or change settings on your computer, generally without appropriately obtaining your consent.
A file containing data where individual field values are separated by a character, such as a comma or a tab.
A grouping of items to which the same discount structure applies.
A tool that lets you enter complex characters and symbols, such as those used in East Asian written languages, using a standard keyboard.
A tool that lets you enter complex characters and symbols, such as those used in East Asian written languages, using a standard keyboard.
A diagram that is used to show areas of overlap between and among elements.
A transaction that modifies a subscription. There are four types of subscription transactions: regular subscription, non-regular subscription, price change, and reduction days.
Pertaining to keyboard settings, document views, user interface objects, languages, etc. for which text is displayed in a right-to-left direction.
Pertaining to keyboard settings, document views, user interface objects, languages, etc. for which text is displayed in a right-to-left direction.

A list that includes the name of the person who originally sent a task request plus the names of everyone who received the task request, reassigned the task to someone else, or chose to keep an updated copy of the task in their task list.

A line printed above, below, or to the side of some element, either to set that item off from the remainder of the page or to improve the look of the page. Footnotes, for example, often appear below a short rule that sets them off from the main text on the page. The thickness of a rule is typically measured in points. (A point is approximately 1/72 inch.)
A feature that allows deletion of the files created during hibernation.
The information about a computer that's derived from the System Information program.
A set of items or devices working together to accomplish a task.
The slide that stores information from the design template pertaining to styles on title slides, including placeholder sizes and positions, background design, and color schemes.
A networking standard that uses cables to provide network access. Ethernet is the most widely installed technology for connecting computers.
A statement of the financial position of an organization that reports the state of assets, liabilities, and equity on a specified date.

The process of building profitable customer relationships through the delivery of highly targeted interactions at all customer touch points by aligning marketing, sales and service functions and systems.

The process of building profitable customer relationships through the delivery of highly targeted interactions at all customer touch points by aligning marketing, sales and service functions and systems.

A character-encoding standard developed by the Unicode Consortium that represents almost all of the written languages of the world. The Unicode character repertoire has multiple representation forms, including UTF-8, UTF-16, and UTF-32. Most Windows interfaces use the UTF-16 form.

A type of display that uses a liquid compound having a polar molecular structure, sandwiched between two transparent electrodes. When an electric field is applied, the molecules align with the field, forming a crystalline arrangement that polarizes the light passing through it. A polarized filter laminated over the electrodes blocks polarized light. In this way, a grid of electrodes can selectively "turn on" a cell, or a pixel, containing the liquid crystal material, turning it dark.

A type of display that uses a liquid compound having a polar molecular structure, sandwiched between two transparent electrodes. When an electric field is applied, the molecules align with the field, forming a crystalline arrangement that polarizes the light passing through it. A polarized filter laminated over the electrodes blocks polarized light. In this way, a grid of electrodes can selectively "turn on" a cell, or a pixel, containing the liquid crystal material, turning it dark.

The registration of an assumed, fictitious, or trade name under which a business operates, which must be included on U.S. tax reports. In the U.S., any business that operates under a name other than a personal or corporate legal name must register a DBA name with the appropriate government agency.

The registration of an assumed, fictitious, or trade name under which a business operates, which must be included on U.S. tax reports. In the U.S., any business that operates under a name other than a personal or corporate legal name must register a DBA name with the appropriate government agency.
An individual or organization that fulfills all or part of a contract from another contractor or subcontractor.
A reference to a range that spans two or more worksheets in a workbook.
A source document that documents a payment request from another party.
A long-range plan for estimating capacity, quantities of finished goods to be sold, and quantities of components needed, and for establishing financial priorities.
A location in a program at which execution is halted so that a programmer can examine the program's status, the contents of variables, and so on.
The release of items from inventory.
The amount of money coming into and going out of a company and the timing of these flows.
A unique bank registration number that a bank uses to identify itself.
A unique bank registration number that a bank uses to identify itself.
A unique bank registration number that a bank uses to identify itself.
A keyboard key that sends the escape (ESC) character to the computer. Often this key moves the user back one level in the menu structure or exits the program.
A section of the U.S. Internal Revenue Service tax code that permits some property (fixed assets) to be expensed in the year it is purchased rather than depreciated over a number of years.
A section of the U.S. Internal Revenue Service tax code that permits some property (fixed assets) to be expensed in the year it is purchased rather than depreciated over a number of years.
A logical relationship established between domains to allow pass-through authentication, in which a trusting domain honors the logon authentications of a trusted domain.
An identification number that is issued by a tax authority to indicate that a company is not required to pay sales tax.
An identification number that is issued by a tax authority to indicate that a company is not required to pay sales tax.
An IP address of the OneNote session that is being shared with other users.
A type of report that contains answers to a questionnaire.
A file and folder structure that contains the necessary files and/or configuration settings that control the preinstallation process and define the manufacturers' custom information.
A feature that identifies people using computers near you so that you can use features and programs that use peer-to-peer technology.
An item assembled for sale using a bill of materials.
Any device that changes electrical signals or computer data from one form to another. For example, an analog-to-digital converter translates analog signals to digital signals.

The process of recalculating an account balance to reflect a change in the exchange rate for transactions in foreign currencies. The transaction gain or loss is considered unrealized if the adjustment is calculated for reporting purposes alone, and realized if the debt is paid or the revenue is received.

A file containing information that the user either requires or will find informative and that might not have been included in the documentation. Readme files are placed on disk in plain-text form (without extraneous or program-specific characters) so that they can be read easily be a variety of word processing programs.

A file containing information that the user either requires or will find informative and that might not have been included in the documentation. Readme files are placed on disk in plain-text form (without extraneous or program-specific characters) so that they can be read easily be a variety of word processing programs.
A type of installation that allows the user to specify certain installation settings and options, such as which components will be installed.
A method for scheduling resources that assumes that all the component materials needed for production are available at the time they are needed.
A method for scheduling resources that assumes that all the component materials needed for production are available at the time they are needed.
The amount of light that is emitted by a computer monitor or picture displayed on the monitor.
An application that is used to open an attachment for Attachment Previewing.

In an environment capable of displaying multiple on-screen windows, any window other than the one currently being used for work. An inactive window can be partially or entirely hidden behind another window, and it remains inactive until the user selects it.

An inventory decrease that has been applied to a specific inventory increase, for the purpose of exact cost reversing. This might be the case, for example, with a purchase return that is applied to a specific purchase receipt.

A revenue or expense account whose balance will be transferred to a retained earnings account at the end of a fiscal year. Balances in profit and loss accounts determine the net income or net loss for the year.
The & character.

An attempt to run a memory operation that the underlying page protection does not allow. An access violation applies to memory operations, but does not apply when the security manager checks user-mode access rights to objects.
The process for generating a timetable for matching supply with demand.

An e-mail folder with associated retention, archive, or expiration policies that are applied to its contents. Organizations can facilitate policy enforcement by providing such folders for users to classify e-mail messages.
A database query and programming language widely used for accessing, querying, updating, and managing data in relational database systems.
A database query and programming language widely used for accessing, querying, updating, and managing data in relational database systems.
The type of record - asset, liability, revenue, expense, or owner's equity - traditionally used for recording individual transactions in an accounting system.

To duplicate information and reproduce it in another part of a document, in a different file or memory location, or in a different medium. A copy operation can affect data ranging from a single character to large segments of text, a graphics image, or from one to many data files.

An international association of 157 countries/regions, each of which is represented by its leading standard-setting organization-for example, ANSI (American National Standards Institute) for the United States. The ISO works to establish global standards for communications and information exchange. Primary among its accomplishments is the widely accepted ISO/OSI reference model, which defines standards for the interaction of computers connected by communications networks.

An international association of 157 countries/regions, each of which is represented by its leading standard-setting organization-for example, ANSI (American National Standards Institute) for the United States. The ISO works to establish global standards for communications and information exchange. Primary among its accomplishments is the widely accepted ISO/OSI reference model, which defines standards for the interaction of computers connected by communications networks.
The cost of retaining inventory, whether raw materials, components, or finished goods. Carrying cost typically is expressed as a percentage of inventory value per year or other time period.
Tiny Japanese kana characters written above or next to kanji characters. The kana characters indicate the correct pronunciation of the word written in kanji.
A directory that you can use to store names, e-mail addresses, fax numbers, and distribution lists.
A directory that you can use to store names, e-mail addresses, fax numbers, and distribution lists.
The consistent vertical positioning of text, graphics, and other objects.
The difference between the perceived value and the book value of an asset.

A key on the keyboard, labeled "Insert" or "Ins", whose usual function is to toggle a program's editing setting between an insert mode and an overwrite mode, although it may perform different functions in different applications.
The examination of a good or service to ensure that it complies with specifications.
A project with a direct customer relation.
A charge made by a bank based on account status or activity such as minimum balance, overdrafts, or nonsufficient funds.
The authentication protocol (such as CHAP, PAP, EAP etc.) used when authenticating access to resources on a network.
An account structure whose valid value combinations are constrained by integrity constraints and account rules.
A card-like layout on an Outlook Contact that provides the user with the look of a real world business card.
A card-like layout on an Outlook Contact that provides the user with the look of a real world business card.
In 2-D stacked bar and column charts, a line that connects the data markers in a data series and is used to emphasize the difference in measurement between each series.
The owners' rights or claims to the assets of a business.
A currency used in a number of European Union countries.
A product or service that a company buys from a vendor and/or sells to a customer.
The primary quotation issued to a customer.
A wizard that helps the user to adjust their speakers for the best sound by running automatic calibration tests for levels, delay, and frequency response.
A source document that documents the item quantities in a shipment.
A report that summarizes the status of an account, including current balance and recent activities.

A marketing program designed to accomplish a specific result, such as introducing a new product or increasing market share. The main way to accomplish this result is through communicating the benefits of a product or service to people and businesses. Campaigns often include more than one communication method, such as print advertisements, promotional discounts, and direct mail.

A marketing program designed to accomplish a specific result, such as introducing a new product or increasing market share. The main way to accomplish this result is through communicating the benefits of a product or service to people and businesses. Campaigns often include more than one communication method, such as print advertisements, promotional discounts, and direct mail.
The pairing of two or more actions that are performed together as a single action; the action succeeds or fails as a whole.
A field that need not contain a value when a record is updated or inserted into the database.
The internationally accepted currency code that represents the Euro currency.
The definite cost incurred in the performance of an activity.
To temporarily suspend an active phone call.
To displace the left or right edge of a text item, such as a block or a line, relative to the margin or to another text item.

For automatic subtotals and worksheet outlines, the subtotal rows or columns that are totaled by summary data. Detail data is typically adjacent to and either above or to the left of the summary data.
A type of bank card where the amount of purchase is immediately withdrawn from the user's bank account.
A type of bank card where the amount of purchase is immediately withdrawn from the user's bank account.
Funds added to an account.

An operation that retrieves rows from multiple source tables by comparing the values from columns shared between the source tables. An inner join excludes rows from a source table that have no matching rows in the other source tables.
An Office feature that allows users to create professional looking information graphics quickly and easily.
An overview presentation of features that can be launched from within the program.
Two arrows in shape of a cross, with two heads each pointing in opposite directions.
To place a file or project back in a source repository. This releases the lock for editing and enables other users to view the updated file or check out the file.
The practice of recording, classifying, summarizing, and reporting the financial consequences of accounting events.
The processor in an imagesetter or desktop printer that interprets the commands sent by a printer driver and converts them to a raster or bitmap grid to mark the paper or film.
The process in which a consumer enters information, such as an e-mail address, to acquire a license.
A combination of table formatting options identified by a style name.
Repeated execution of one or more statements or instructions. Statements or instructions so executed are said to be in a loop.
The text string that appears in place of an image when a Web page is loading, when graphics are not being displayed, or when users pause on the image itself with their mouse.
A feature that enables the user to access Outlook data over the Internet without a VPN connection.
Software that is used to compress or decompress a digital media file.
A modem constructed on an expansion card to be installed in one of the expansion slots inside a computer.
Someone granted permission to access items or perform functions on another user's behalf.

The name of a pane at the bottom of the Calendar module where tasks are displayed. Tasks that are completed on a particular day "stick" to the day and are shown as a record of what work was performed on that day. Tasks not completed roll over to the next day and accumulate until completed.
An item on the user's My Status menu that resets the user's status to the previous setting after the user has manually selected a status setting.
A field that is assigned a series orientation in a PivotChart report. In a chart, series are represented in the legend.
A system transaction that tracks and reports what has been posted to the ledger.
A status that indicates that an active telephone call has been temporarily suspended.
A note alongside the main text that contains interesting or useful information.
A feature that may be able to identify the root cause of crashes if an Office application is repeatedly crashing.
The blank space outside the printing area on a page.
The blank space outside the printing area on a page.

A special AutoText entry that stores multiple deletions. Microsoft Office Word appends one item to another until you paste the contents as a group in a new location in your document. You can also use the Microsoft Office Clipboard to get the same result.
An inventory valuation method in which inventory that is received most recently is considered sold or used first for accounting purposes.

termGrp.term: last in, first out inventory valuation method

descripGrp.descrip: An inventory valuation method in which inventory that is received most recently is considered sold or used first for accounting purposes.
A credit animation in Windows Movie Maker.
A method for specifying the consumption of sales forecast requirements and purchase forecast requirements that are used in master scheduling.
A sequence of averages computed from parts of a data series. In a chart, a moving average smooths the fluctuations in data, thus showing the pattern or trend more clearly.
To make a form, view, device or other resource available over a network.

Information displayed to a user about someone else adding him or her to a contact list, a contact's offline or online status, a missed conversation, voice mail message, service problem, or other item.
A miniature version of an image that is often used for quick browsing through multiple images.
A miniature version of an image that is often used for quick browsing through multiple images.
The date that an asset is acquired.
A dictionary with words that the main dictionary recognizes as being spelled correctly, but that you want to verify during a spelling check.
The top level of a business hierarchy.
An independent section on a webpage. Each frame is actually a separate webpage and can have its own scrollbars.

An application that consolidates a user's voice mail, fax, and e-mail into one mailbox, so that the user only needs to check a single location for messages, regardless of type. The e-mail server is used as the platform for all types of messages, making it unnecessary to maintain separate voice mail and e-mail infrastructures.

An application that consolidates a user's voice mail, fax, and e-mail into one mailbox, so that the user only needs to check a single location for messages, regardless of type. The e-mail server is used as the platform for all types of messages, making it unnecessary to maintain separate voice mail and e-mail infrastructures.
The sender's address, to which a letter or parcel can be returned if undeliverable.
A tool in Windows Defender that can be to used change how a program runs on the computer if the program is causing a problem.
A spreadsheet that contains information about a shape; for example, its dimensions, angle, and center of rotation and the styles that determine the shape's appearance.
Tasks that a user is permitted to perform on a computer system or domain.
Tasks that a user is permitted to perform on a computer system or domain.
A field that can contain a value that is used in a query.
A series of instructions that is repeated a fixed number of times or until a terminating condition is reached.
The process of temporarily storing recently accessed information in a special memory subsystem for quicker access.
Specification that the volume or quantity of a component used in a finished item is proportional to the number of items produced or reported as finished.

In general, a modular unit of code that acts as part of a larger system or structure. For COM, a unit of code built to deliver a well-specified set of services through well-specified interfaces. A component provides an object that a client requests at runtime.
The categorization of an inventory item based on its value compared to the total inventory on hand.

User's perception about the utility usability and desirability of a product as they integrate it into their lives and their family system. The user experience will be the differentiator that drives adoption and use of hardware software and services.
In an online forum, such as a newsgroup, a series of messages or articles in which replies to an message are nested directly under it instead of arranged in chronological or alphabetical order.

Information that includes identification and proof of identification that is used to gain access to local and network resources. Examples of credentials are user names and passwords, smart cards, and certificates.

Information that includes identification and proof of identification that is used to gain access to local and network resources. Examples of credentials are user names and passwords, smart cards, and certificates.

Information that includes identification and proof of identification that is used to gain access to local and network resources. Examples of credentials are user names and passwords, smart cards, and certificates.
A technology that is based on the Component Object Model (COM) that enables interoperability among ActiveX components, including OLE components. Formerly referred to as OLE Automation.
A feature that consists of advanced text wrap functionality, allowing the user to select from various styles to specify how text flows around objects or graphics in a document.

The three-dimensional space that is defined by a set of coordinates for representing color on devices such as monitors, scanners, and printers. For example, in the LAB color space, the colors are defined in terms of their luminance or whiteness (L), redness-greenness (A), and yellowness-blueness (B); the HVC system uses hue (H), value (V), and chroma (C). The two most common color space models are RGB and YUV.
The process of breaking a word between syllables at the end of a line or to separate the parts of a compound word.
A 32-bit integer that identifies a property set.

An encryption algorithm that uses a 56-bit key and maps a 64-bit input block to a 64-bit output block. The key appears to be a 64-bit key, but one bit in each of the eight bytes is used for odd parity, resulting in 56 bits of usable key.

An encryption algorithm that uses a 56-bit key and maps a 64-bit input block to a 64-bit output block. The key appears to be a 64-bit key, but one bit in each of the eight bytes is used for odd parity, resulting in 56 bits of usable key.
A special kind of transformation whereby an XML document is converted from one XML schema to another.
To withdraw items from inventory for production or distribution.

Total values for all cells in a row or all cells in a column of a PivotTable report. Values in a grand total row or column are calculated by using the same summary function used in the data area of the PivotTable report.
The reversal of an inventory transaction, using the same cost for the reversing transaction, for example a return order or a credit memo, as was used in the original transaction.
A mode that enables the user to move a document by dragging it. Panning mode is available when a Word document is displayed on a preview pane.
A calendaring feature that automatically manages resources. Resource requests are automatically accepted or denied depending on availability and policies.

An enhanced spell-check feature that looks at words before or after the word in question to assess proper usage. This allows the software to flag correctly-spelled words as 'wrong' if the usage appears to be incorrect.

An optical device found in scanners and fax machines that moves across the subject being scanned, converts light and dark areas to electrical signals, and sends those signals to the scanning system for processing.
A set of extensions to the Hypertext Transfer Protocol (HTTP) that facilitates collaborative editing and file management between users located remotely from each other on the Internet.
A set of extensions to the Hypertext Transfer Protocol (HTTP) that facilitates collaborative editing and file management between users located remotely from each other on the Internet.
A set of extensions to the Hypertext Transfer Protocol (HTTP) that facilitates collaborative editing and file management between users located remotely from each other on the Internet.

termGrp.term: World Wide Web Distributed Authoring and Versioning
World Wide Web Distributed Authoring and Versioning

descripGrp.descrip: A set of extensions to the Hypertext Transfer Protocol (HTTP) that facilitates collaborative editing and file management between users located remotely from each other on the Internet.
An electronic version of a user guide or manual that will release with the software.
A session in which multiple users can work together and see each other’s changes immediately.
A session in which multiple users can work together and see each other’s changes immediately.
A journal that is used to post intercompany payments.
An external file included with an e-mail message.

The propagation of properties via InfoPath forms from the underlying data into named properties in Outlook or SharePoint sites. Promoted properties are used to group, filter, and sort data, files, and folders.
A bill of exchange that has been settled.
A model for creating sales quotations. The template includes common information so that it does not need to be entered each time a quotation is created.
The combination of an Active Directory user object that has mailbox attributes and the associated mailbox data that is stored in the mailbox database.
An account number scheme that is recognized by banks internationally to facilitate credit transfers across national/regional borders.
An account number scheme that is recognized by banks internationally to facilitate credit transfers across national/regional borders.
An area of the window that displays a limited view of search results or other content.
In an organization chart, a shape that is placed above and connected to any other shape, such as an employee (subordinate or coworker shape) or assistant shape.
A specific Office icon that is used within a group to launch a related dialog box.
The family of Microsoft server products that support large scale implementation management of enterprise application integration processes.
The family of Microsoft server products that support large scale implementation management of enterprise application integration processes.
In a graphical user interface such as Windows, a pattern or picture in the screen background that can be chosen by the user.

A member of the TCP/IP suite of protocols, used to copy files between two computers on the Internet. Both computers must support their respective FTP roles: one must be an FTP client and the other an FTP server.

A member of the TCP/IP suite of protocols, used to copy files between two computers on the Internet. Both computers must support their respective FTP roles: one must be an FTP client and the other an FTP server.
A collection of binaries that can be installed on top of the core product and enables users to select a preferred language so that the user interface and Help files appear in that preferred language.

A common programming interface to the lower-level system area network (SAN) implementations, developed by Microsoft. WSD sits underneath the standard WinSock application programming interface (API), but bypasses the kernel networking layers to talk directly to the SAN hardware. Because WSD sits underneath the existing WinSock API, IT departments can deploy applications in a SAN environment without modifying the applications.

A common programming interface to the lower-level system area network (SAN) implementations, developed by Microsoft. WSD sits underneath the standard WinSock application programming interface (API), but bypasses the kernel networking layers to talk directly to the SAN hardware. Because WSD sits underneath the existing WinSock API, IT departments can deploy applications in a SAN environment without modifying the applications.
A collection of files, managed by a manifest.xml file, that add functionality to a Microsoft Office Word or Microsoft Office Excel document by specifying custom display or actions.
A sequence of declarations and statements that are executed as a unit.

An electronic system of transmitting transient images of fixed or moving objects together with sound through space by an apparatus that converts light and sound into electrical waves and reconverts them into visible light rays and audible sound.

An electronic system of transmitting transient images of fixed or moving objects together with sound through space by an apparatus that converts light and sound into electrical waves and reconverts them into visible light rays and audible sound.

A temporary property of a user-interface object, such as a window, view, dialog box, or button, that permits the object to receive keyboard input from the user. The focus is usually conveyed through highlighting.

A security group that can be granted rights and permissions only to resources on the computer on which the group is created. Local groups can have any user accounts that are local to the computer as members, as well as users, groups, and computers from a domain to which the computer belongs.
A technical document in the Microsoft Knowledge Base accessible through Microsoft.com.
A user dictionary that contains a list of words not in the application dictionary that an author wants the spelling checker to accept as correct.
A formula syntax that allows the user to refer to list and pivot data in a friendlier way.
A classification for grouping content by user-defined criteria such as page contents, file types, or a similar distinction.
A problem that prevents sync from completing. Sync errors are typically caused by problems with the device, network folder, or other computer you are trying to sync with.

A stand-alone, dynamic-link library that, when loaded, can add custom commands that extend the functionality of Microsoft Word. Commands and functions in a loaded WLL are also available to Microsoft Visual Basic projects.

A stand-alone, dynamic-link library that, when loaded, can add custom commands that extend the functionality of Microsoft Word. Commands and functions in a loaded WLL are also available to Microsoft Visual Basic projects.
An adjustment to increase the value of a fixed asset for accounting purposes.
A filter effect in Windows Movie Maker.
A button on the address bar that enables the user to navigate to the specified location (such as a folder path or web address).
A set of integrated tools for developing software. The tools are generally run from one user interface and consist of a compiler, an editor, and a debugger, among others.
A set of integrated tools for developing software. The tools are generally run from one user interface and consist of a compiler, an editor, and a debugger, among others.
A person whose work or profession is management.
A structured set of activities designed to yield a specified result or output.
The program that installs or upgrades the Windows operating system.
The bill that an organization receives when a purchase is made.
A building or structure where materials or goods are stored on an interim basis until they are transferred to their destination.
An advertiser's association with a Web site that can involve financial or material support in return for increased visibility perceived advantage over run-of-site advertising and a targeted audience.

The record of an Edge Transport server that has been subscribed to an Exchange organization and to which the Microsoft Exchange EdgeSync service propagates recipient and configuration data. The Microsoft Exchange EdgeSync service relies on Edge Subscriptions. Also, Edge Subscription is the process that is required to establish an Edge Subscription for a given Edge Transport server.
A number of days added to receipts to inventory, such as purchases, to protect against unplanned delays.
Having values separated from each other by tabs.
Having values separated from each other by tabs.
A method of calculating the depreciation of a fixed asset as a fixed percentage of its net book value at the start of each depreciation period.
A type of assessment principle that specifies that revenue and costs are recognized when contract activity is completed.
A value shown in Excel when there is an error in a formula, for example #VALUE! or #REF!.
A menu item that provides options for restarting or turning off your computer or device, or for activating Stand By or Hibernate modes.
A method of accelerated depreciation permitted by tax codes that classifies depreciable assets into one of several recovery periods, each of which has a designated pattern of allowable depreciation.
A method of accelerated depreciation permitted by tax codes that classifies depreciable assets into one of several recovery periods, each of which has a designated pattern of allowable depreciation.

A reference number that is used to authorize and track goods returned for repair or refund. A return materials authorization is issued by a sales entity that authorizes a buying company to return goods.

A reference number that is used to authorize and track goods returned for repair or refund. A return materials authorization is issued by a sales entity that authorizes a buying company to return goods.
A predefined command for a single mouse click or a double mouse click, with or without a modifier key, that can be used to perform a task.
The state of an uninitialized Variant variable (which returns a VarType of 0).

A type of list task page where the primary action is selecting an entity from the list. Users access the advanced list through the Advanced link on the dropdown list. If the user cannot find the information they need on the simple drop-down list, they may choose to view the more complete advanced list where they can view all the fields for a particular entity.
A set of formatting characteristics that you can apply to text, tables, and lists in your document to quickly change their appearance.
A name that uniquely identifies a server computer on a network.
To display only the rows in a list that satisfy the conditions you specify. You use the AutoFilter command to display rows that match one or more specific values, calculated values, or conditions.
The application that helps the user to activate a Windows product with Microsoft.

An 8-byte, fixed-point data type that is useful for calculations involving money or for fixed-point calculations in which accuracy is extremely important. The Currency data type is used to store numbers with up to 15 digits to the left of the decimal point and 4 digits to the right. The type-declaration character in Microsoft© Visual Basic© is an at sign (@). Currency can range from -922,337,203,685,477.5808 to 922,337,203,685,477.5807.

A query that calculates a sum, average, count, or other type of total on records, and then groups the result by two types of information: one down the left side of the datasheet and the other across the top.
A common drop-down menu that includes commands for file operations, such as Open, Save, and Print.
The time to which a clock is set.
An amount of money sent to or from an account in a bank.
A 16-bit vector graphics format for Windows-compatible computers used mostly as a clip art format in word-processing documents.

A form of storage characterized by high capacity (roughly 650 MB) and the use of laser optics rather than magnetic means for reading data. Optical disk storage commonly used for audio, video, and computer data. DVDs range in capacity from 4.7 GB to 17 GB, and can store significantly more than a CD-ROM.

A form of storage characterized by high capacity (roughly 650 MB) and the use of laser optics rather than magnetic means for reading data. Optical disk storage commonly used for audio, video, and computer data. DVDs range in capacity from 4.7 GB to 17 GB, and can store significantly more than a CD-ROM.
The accuracy of data and its conformity to its expected value, especially after being transmitted or processed.
The accuracy of data and its conformity to its expected value, especially after being transmitted or processed.
To add money to an account.
Software used to scan for and eradicate computer viruses, worms, and trojan horses.
The process of converting encrypted content back into its original form to make it readable again. This is also called converting ciphertext back to plaintext.
A calendar that defines the capacity and work time in a production system, for use in managing work centers or work center groups.
An image that has been captured electronically with a digital camera or scanner.
The inability to perform two or more activities because they have been scheduled to occur during the same time period and with the same resource or resources.
In a graphical user interface such as Windows, a pattern or picture in the screen background that can be chosen by the user.
In a graphical user interface such as Windows, a pattern or picture in the screen background that can be chosen by the user.
In a graphical user interface such as Windows, a pattern or picture in the screen background that can be chosen by the user.
In a graphical user interface such as Windows, a pattern or picture in the screen background that can be chosen by the user.
To attach a label to.

On IBM and PC-compatible computers, a key whose function changes depending on the application program. Usually it erases the character under the cursor, although in some applications it can erase selected text or graphics.

Extra depreciation amounts that can be taken in the first year that an asset is placed in service and depreciated. Bonus depreciation is taken before any other depreciation is calculated and is available only for depreciation books.
One of several predefined rules for calculating depreciation in the year of the acquisition of the asset and the year of the disposal of the asset.
To wait for incoming traffic, calls or connection requests on a port.
To be unresponsive.
A tool for accessing right-click menus and targeting small pieces of the interface using touch input.
The assignment of a specific role that determines whether a user or group can access a specific item and perform an operation on it.

A method of depreciation that calculates the depreciation of a fixed asset as a fixed amount in each depreciation period. There will be a difference in the depreciation amount calculated between straight-line service life remaining and straight-line service life when there is an adjustment posted to the asset.

termGrp.term: straight-line service life remaining depreciation method

descripGrp.descrip: The location to which goods are to be sent.

An application of the Standard Generalized Markup Language that uses tags to mark elements, such as text and graphics, in a document to indicate how Web browsers should display these elements to the user and should respond to user actions.

An application of the Standard Generalized Markup Language that uses tags to mark elements, such as text and graphics, in a document to indicate how Web browsers should display these elements to the user and should respond to user actions.
A source document that documents the requirements for producing items to meet a demand.
A form of assistance in which a program that provides on-screen help shows information to the user concerning the current command or operation being attempted.
A list of domain names and e-mail addresses that are treated as junk e-mail and are blocked unless the sender is on the Safe Senders List or the recipient is on the Safe Recipients List.

In the United States, a 9-digit number that identifies a business entity to the government. A business must have an EIN if it has employees or meets other criteria specified by the federal government.

In the United States, a 9-digit number that identifies a business entity to the government. A business must have an EIN if it has employees or meets other criteria specified by the federal government.

In the United States, a 9-digit number that identifies a business entity to the government. A business must have an EIN if it has employees or meets other criteria specified by the federal government.

In the United States, a 9-digit number that identifies a business entity to the government. A business must have an EIN if it has employees or meets other criteria specified by the federal government.
A record of sales and purchase transactions for sales tax reporting in Italy.
A device or part of a device that receives something from another device.
The amount per unit an item is sold for.
A collection of Microsoft Management Console (MMC) snap-ins that Microsoft Exchange provides.
A copy of a master, which you create by dragging the master from a stencil to a drawing.
An item in the Journal folder that acts as a shortcut to an activity that has been recorded.

The Book.xlt template that you create to change the default format of new workbooks. Excel uses the template to create a blank workbook when you start Excel or create a new workbook without specifying a template.
A search technology used to separate text into individual words.
To activate or turn on.
To activate or turn on.
A visual display of data in a dashboard that can be coordinated with other report views by using filters.
A value that represents the result of an invalid calculation.
The process of writing new data to computer memory.

An icon that represents the current location being played within the selected media. As clips are being played it moves along the timeline of events to the nearest frame boundary. The positioning of the icon is always between two frames. The preview area will display the frame to the right of the current location.
A color that is mixed with black. A 10-percent shade is one part of the original color and nine parts black.
Settings that enable parents to restrict what their children see.
Combined earphone and microphone set that enables hands-free communication.
The process of coordinating the operation of the various programs, databases, and existing technologies of a business or enterprise so that they function as an efficient, business-wide system.
The process of coordinating the operation of the various programs, databases, and existing technologies of a business or enterprise so that they function as an efficient, business-wide system.
The process of coordinating the operation of the various programs, databases, and existing technologies of a business or enterprise so that they function as an efficient, business-wide system.
The process of coordinating the operation of the various programs, databases, and existing technologies of a business or enterprise so that they function as an efficient, business-wide system.
The slide text on the slide master. The master text determines the format of text on all slides as well as the shape of text placeholders and their placement on slides.
The naming convention for disk drives or partitions on most computers, consisting of an alphabetical letter followed by a colon.
A numeric value that corresponds to a particular character in a set.

An internal company that acts as a customer to another internal company. When a company does not satisfy an original sales order, that company becomes an intercompany customer when it directs a purchase order to another internal company to satisfy the original sales order.
A control on a form, that repeats as needed, into which users can enter text. The control can be formatted as a bulleted, numbered, or plain list.
The appearance of the Start menu and the taskbar after the glass visual style has been applied to customize the color, intensity, and opacity of window borders.
An element that is required to be present in order to satisfy a schema.
The lead time for an intercompany sales order.

A custom word or phrase that the administrator sets for the Content Filter agent to prevent e-mail messages that contain specific words or phrases from being delivered to Exchange Server 2007 mailbox users.
An icon that designates a change made by a reviewer to a presentation.
A second calendar format selected by the user from within Outlook and visible in dual calendar view.
A sequence of words or other text used to gain access to a network, program, or data. A passphrase is generally longer for added security.
A folder that exists by default in all users’ mailboxes. The Inbox, Outbox, Sent Items, Deleted Items, Calendar, and Contacts folders are default folders.
A task pane with options that enable the user to send a Publisher file as personalized, individually addressed e-mail to the recipients in the specified list.
The process of copying content and/or configuration settings from one location, generally a server node, to another. Replication is done to ensure synchronization or fault tolerance.
A typographical unit of measure that is equal to one sixth of an inch.
The process of moving an item to the Deleted Items folder.
The ratio of profitability calculated by dividing net income by owners' equity.
A OneNote item that has been marked with a note tag.
A configuration parameter or element that controls the behavior of a service, application, feature, function, or a run-time environment.
A route through a structured collection of information, as in a database, a program, or files stored on disk.
To align text along the right margin.
The area in each row of a database table that stores the data value for some attribute of the object modeled by the table.
An item that deletes a selected contact from a contact group, when the contact is right-clicked.
A title animation in Windows Movie Maker.
The protection of information assets through the use of technology, processes, and training.
Goods or merchandise that a customer returns to the place of purchase or that a borrower returns to a lender.
The point at which one page ends and another begins.

The full Internet address of a page or other World Wide Web resource. The absolute URL includes a protocol, such as "http," network location, and optional path and file name — for example, http://example.microsoft.com/.
A method computers use to send and receive e-mail messages. It allows you to access e-mail without downloading it to your computer or device.
A method computers use to send and receive e-mail messages. It allows you to access e-mail without downloading it to your computer or device.

A Microsoft Exchange mailbox that allocates a specific number of connections. The resource serves as a virtual room for your online meeting. You invite the resource to an online meeting just as you would reserve a room for a meeting.
A menu choice or remote button that offers access to the user's video library.

A small, Internet Protocol (IP)-based network. It is usually used for short-range, ad-hoc communication between devices and computers. A PAN may also be used to enable connectivity to a larger Local Area Network (LAN), Wide-Area Network (WAN), or the Internet. Windows XP supports the Bluetooth PAN service so you can create Personal Area Networks using Bluetooth.

A small, Internet Protocol (IP)-based network. It is usually used for short-range, ad-hoc communication between devices and computers. A PAN may also be used to enable connectivity to a larger Local Area Network (LAN), Wide-Area Network (WAN), or the Internet. Windows XP supports the Bluetooth PAN service so you can create Personal Area Networks using Bluetooth.
The underlying technology of the Exchange Server content filter that evaluates inbound mail and assesses the probability that an inbound e-mail message is either a legitimate message or spam.

Authorization to perform operations associated with a specific shared resource, such as a file, directory, or printer. Permissions must be granted by the system administrator to individual user accounts or administrative groups.

Authorization to perform operations associated with a specific shared resource, such as a file, directory, or printer. Permissions must be granted by the system administrator to individual user accounts or administrative groups.
An option that changes a 2-dimensional linear expression, such as 5^2, to a built-up (3-dimensional) format.
The ultimate user of a computer or computer application in its finished, marketable form.
A reference to a specific legal case, statute, or other legal document.
A person who is involved in the creation of content. For example editors, technical reviewers and subject matter experts are contributors.
The amount of space from the bottom of one line of text to the bottom of the next line.
The amount of space from the bottom of one line of text to the bottom of the next line.
A status notification that the device is not within the wireless service range.
A feature that allows you to associate one or more links (URLs) with a specific record in Dynamics NAV.
A value assigned to an item of media content that indicates its suitability for a particular audience.
A dialog box that allows users to add/remove/organize the list of bibliographic information for the document

Functionality available on Receive connectors and Send connectors on the Exchange Server 2007 Edge Transport server that lets e-mail administrators modify the SMTP addresses of senders and recipients on messages that enter and leave an Exchange organization. Address rewriting lets an organization present a consistent appearance to external recipients of messages from the organization.
A reference to an entity of a specific entity type.

A keyboard character that can be used to represent one or many characters when conducting a query.
